##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem. -->
We use a Git repository where we commit playbooks in, this Git repo is defined as a project in AWX.
Jobs are launched, using this project.
The "scm update options" are all disabled in the project settings.

Our flow compares the Git revision with the one of the AWX project, and triggers a project_update when it's different.

We noticed that when a job is running, the scm update remains in a pending state until the job is finished, and only starts after the job has finished.


##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 2.1.2.0
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.7.4
* Operating System: Debian

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
<!-- Please describe exactly how to reproduce the problem. -->
Commit a playbook to Git
Run a project update
Run a playbook job
Commit another playbook to Git
Run a project update

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
<!-- What did you expect to happen when running the steps above? -->
The 2nd project update is executed during the 1st playbook job execution

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
<!-- What actually happened? -->
The 2nd project update remains pending, until the 1st playbook job is finished

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->

When running ansible-playbook outside of AWX, and changing the contents of a  role/playbook/... during this run, the playbook run is not affected by these changes.
Why does an SCM project update in AWX wait until a job is finished, I would think the project update wouldn't impact any running jobs?

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Right now, an inventory source type can only have one instance_id value.

This issue is to allow a list of values for instance_id, where it will find the identifier by looking at the first one, and the falling back to the 2nd, 3rd, etc.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

The reason is that the inventory plugins have changed the keys for hostvars, including the ones we use for instance_ids.

If we ever allow the YAML inventory config to be customizable (and we should), then we need to anticipate the scenario where we get the instance ID by the new name but not the old name.

Concretely...

| Source   | old key | new key     |
|----------|---------|-------------|
| ec2      | ec2_id  | instance_id |
| gce      | gce_id  | id          |
| azure_rm | id      | id          |

In https://github.com/ansible/awx/pull/3266, we have a solution to create the old key via the `compose` options from the old key. That will work for now, but again, we want to allow user customizations. We don't want to constrain them. Solving this issue will allows us to allow the users to remove that variable translation.

So, not urgent, but definitely what we want long-term. Ping @kdelee @wenottingham

 - Documentation

<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API
 - UI
 - Installer

##### SUMMARY
I'm running into challenges getting AWX scaled up in Kubernetes to higher instance counts, specifically that it is overwhelming our PostgreSQL 9.6 external database with connections. Our target instance count is 16, and we're seeing PostgreSQL connection counts climbing the hundreds until we hit `max_connections`. With PostgreSQL being so heavy connection-wise, we're trying to keep the number of connections to a reasonable number.

I've tried multiplexing connections via pgbouncer. In `session` pool mode there doesn't seem to be much change other than AWX creating more and more connections until they get queued instead of refused.

 In `transaction`pool mode the cluster heartbeat tasks intermittently fail due to the use of advisory locks, so it seems the usual methods of multiplexing connections are non-starters.

I've also tried using persistent connections (`CONN_MAX_AGE: None`) and closing connections immediately (`CONN_MAX_AGE: 0`) in combination with session pool_mode, but I'm not coming across a configuration that prevents connections from continuing to grow and grow until they either queue or are refused. 

Is there any documentation or design guidance around scaling to higher instance counts for the PostgreSQL side of the equation?

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 2.1.2
* AWX install method: kubernetes with external PGSQL db
* Ansible version:  latest (multiple venvs)

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Configure external PostgreSQL database, scale up number of AWX instances until PostgreSQL `max_connections` is reached. The connections are idle most of the time.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

AWX re-uses one database connection per container when `CONN_MAX_AGE: None`, will close the connection when `CONN_MAX_AGE: 0` for re-use by the pool,  or can handle pgbouncer multiplexing in `transaction` pool mode. I would expect a max of 64 db connections for 16 instances * 4 containers per instance.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

For 16 instances, and more connections were desired by AWX at the time of this query.
```
awx=# SELECT  * FROM
(SELECT count(*) used, state FROM pg_stat_activity GROUP BY 2) q1,
(SELECT setting::INT res_for_super FROM pg_settings WHERE name=$$superuser_reserved_connections$$) q2,
(SELECT setting::INT max_conn FROM pg_settings WHERE name=$$max_connections$$) q3;
```

 - UI

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem or desired enhancement. -->
Currently if we traverse to SETTINGS > SYSTEM we have a option `ORGANIZATION ADMINS CAN MANAGE USERS AND TEAMS` through which an Org Admin can manage both Users and Teams if turned On. But it'll be nice if we have two separate options `ORGANIZATION ADMINS CAN MANAGE USERS` and `ORGANIZATION ADMINS CAN MANAGE TEAMS` so that it'll easy to delegate permission to org Admin for user/team management.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

 - UI

##### SUMMARY
Notify the awx and tower user of new releases in the UI. If we notify users of awx and tower of our new releases within the UI:
- We can encourage users to keep up with development
- Increase general awareness of our new release cadence
- Encourage users to migrate away from deprecated versions of Tower

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

We could do this through pendo guides or a navbar item. Maybe a notification bell?
This could double as a way to inform users that their version of tower is out of date or about to hit EOL.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem or desired enhancement. -->
Allow venv to be set on inventory source and use default of the ansible venv we ship.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
This is my idea to resolve a usability issue that has come to my attention. If users are using the Organization level VENV, we may put them at risk of breaking their inventory updates.

* If they use ansible 2.3 in this venv, which we still allow in custom venvs, their inventory updates will be completely broken because we call `ansible-inventory` which does not exist in this version

* They may be used to letting their jobs run in a special venv that they love but does not provide necessary dependencies that the inventory sources they rely on need. Their inventory updates may start blowing up/breaking and they be confused as to why it used to work, and it may not be obvious to them that NOW their inventory updates are happening in the venv set at the org level and they are missing dependencies

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->

##### SUMMARY
See https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/52748

Ansible core is moving to a default behavior where group name characters which are not alphanumeric get automatically replaced with underscores.

Inventory sources, those should be covered by Ansible core behavior. Manually entered names should be validated.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API (probably)
 - UI (yes)

##### SUMMARY
Currently, we display this type of information on the job details panel:

![job_error_details](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9753817/53586211-aea7c400-3b55-11e9-9fb0-ac8ea6529cdd.png)

This can be hard to read. It would be better if we represented these errors and tracebacks as if they were job output instead.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
A job can fail, stop running, or unexpectedly not start for a variety of reasons. In the API, we send this information using several different fields depending on context:

- `job.license_error` (bool):
to indicate a license error of some kind
- `job.org_host_limit_error` (string):
to indicate an error due to hitting the host limit for an organization (see [#3174](https://github.com/ansible/awx/pull/3174/files#diff-a000eec9bcdc95dd30b2269e9e3d4c76R239))
- `job.result_traceback` (string):
for issues that caused a traceback prior to a job run.
- `job.job_explanation` ([sometimes a string](https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/awx/main/models/unified_jobs.py#L1228), sometimes a [part-string, part-stringified-json-hybrid](https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/awx/main/tests/unit/models/test_inventory.py#L35) that needs to be [split and parsed.](https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/awx/ui/client/features/output/details.component.js#L396-#L401)):
for other occurrences, like failed inventory syncs.

The work here would probably entail:
- API side, see if it's feasible to represent this information in the job details in a more consolidated or consistent way. This isn't strictly necessary - All of the information is technically there, but it could be helpful for the ui changes that would follow.
- Remove code that shows this information from [the job details panel component](https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/awx/ui/client/features/output/details.component.js)
- Add a function to the [top-level job output controller](https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/awx/ui/client/features/output/index.controller.js) that knows how to take information from these fields when it exists (e.g: `resource.model.get('result_traceback')` and generate a 'fake' job event, complete with ansi stdout fields, counters, etc, which can be pushed into the `render` service and displayed as if it were job output. 
 - Use this function on initialization for finished jobs and also with our `sync` function that we invoke when jobs finish running.

##### SUMMARY
It would be cool if AWX could be configured to prevent launching of tasks for example if 90% of RAM is actively being used by instance where AWX runs. Right now it's not connected to OS resources in any way, which requires very inefficient setup (in peaks AWX uses about 15GB RAM, but most of time about 5GB, yet we had to add 16GB to VM where it run just to avoid swap-death of peaks).

In simple words: check instance resources before launching a job - if there is too much RAM / CPU used, keep job pending until resources are available.

```
---
- hosts: localhost

    - set_stats:
```

- test2.yml

```

- hosts: localhost
```

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API


##### SUMMARY
Unexpected smart inventory query appears when smart inventory query with 3 or more `and` used for ansible facts. For a system with a large smart inventory this results in slow job event processing.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* Tower 3.4.1

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

For slowness of job event processing:
* Create an inventory with at least 3,000 hosts
* Create 60 smart inventories that matches a fraction of those hosts, say 300.
* use a host_filter with at least 3 and's ie. `ansible_facts__ansible_distribution=CentOS and ansible_facts__ansible_distribution=CentOS and ansible_facts__ansible_distribution=CentOS`
* Run a playbook against any of the smart inventories.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

* Shortly after ansible job finishes, stdout shows in the UI

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

* job events take a _long_ time to be processed (> 500 ms per event). This is observable in the UI/API

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

https://gist.github.com/chrismeyersfsu/f0a5e6109cc134a533c7e9d0b2ba5cb4 <-- can be used to log all queries issued in tower along with a stack trace.

`SELECT "main_host"."id", "main_host"."created", "main_host"."modified", "main_host"."description", "main_host"."created_by_id", "main_host"."modified_by_id", "main_host"."name", "main_host"."inventory_id", "main_host"."enabled", "main_host"."instance_id", "main_host"."variables", "main_host"."last_job_id", "main_host"."last_job_host_summary_id", "main_host"."has_active_failures", "main_host"."has_inventory_sources", "main_host"."ansible_facts", "main_host"."ansible_facts_modified", "main_host"."insights_system_id" FROM "main_host" WHERE ("main_host"."ansible_facts" @> '{"ansible_local": {"ansible_distribution": "CentOS"}' AND "main_host"."ansible_facts" @> '{"ansible_local": {"ansible_distribution": "CentOS"}}') ORDER BY "main_host"."name" ASC` <-- This is the offending query. We should NOT generate a query of this type if things are working correctly.

##### SUMMARY
GCE imported hosts should have an instance id

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 3.3.0
* AWX install method: all
* Ansible version:  >=2.5?
* Operating System:
* Web Browser:

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Perform an import with a gce inventory source

Inspect `instance_id` of a host that was imported.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

A long, uuid-ish, kind of string

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Blank string

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

The inventory plugin makes the host name configurable:

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/plugins/inventory/gcp_compute.html

> A list of options that describe the ordering for which hostnames should be assigned. Currently supported hostnames are 'public_ip', 'private_ip', or 'name'.

A configurable host name goes with an unset instance_id like oil and water go together. It is bad news. Any import will changed settings will lose referential integrity, duplicate hosts, and there will be no way to get it back short of a database restore.

https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/e23fb31a4a18c264e9509ba325ecf1372d60b87a/awx/settings/defaults.py#L809

Instead of `None`, this should probably be "id", from a quick glance into hostvars.<sup>[citation needed]</sup>

This necessitates a migration. Instance IDs have never been applied to a previously-existing type to my knowledge.

##### Feature request We would like to request interactive workflows. Our company's workflow would be to run a playbook in check mode with the --diff long-switch to show operators what would change in the configuration. Once the job finished, we would like to prompt the operator an inputfield (eg. survey) where they can opt whether to continue or not. The operator reviews changes, and if selects continue, the same jobtemplate is run in run mode, to commit changes. The interactivity beats scheduling, as it needs human interaction. Our idea is to have two types of workflows: interactive(non-schedulable) and non-interactive(schedulable). These properties would be mutually exclusive. ##### COMPONENT NAME - awx/main/models ? - API - UI ##### SUMMARY We would like to have interactive workflows for operators. ##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY

Right now, custom venvs live in `/var/lib/awx/venv` alongside the system `awx` and `ansible` venvs.

When building a deployment that has multiple custom venvs, you need to:
- build them all into the container image
- volume mount each one individually in `/var/lib/awx/venv` (presumably, haven not tested)

It may be useful to have a specific, configurable, location to search for custom venvs. In this case, a deployment could have a specific volume/mount that contains all of their venvs.

Complication: the path-specific-ness of venvs may imply that the user's choice here affects how they build the venv. 

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

UI mentioned merely because if this is a setting, it would need exposed in settings.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
The Ansible openstack inventory script was renamed.

This is an outline of things that need to happen in order to avoid updating to the renamed script.

The inventory plugin will replace the script

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Our current os-client-config dependency comes from the `shade` library. Both are needed for the current inventory script.

`os-client-config==1.29.0`

If you dig, you will find that the `openstack` import was introduced going from `1.30.0` --> `1.31.0`

https://github.com/openstack/os-client-config/commit/5c2eae8f8242332aff59d18b45a7d17f01524aaa

If that import is present, it conflicts with the _local_ file named `openstack.py`, and will break openstack inventory updates.

```
  File "/awx_devel/awx/plugins/inventory/openstack.py", line 66, in <module>
    import os_client_config
  File "/venv/python2_ansible24/lib/python2.7/site-packages/os_client_config/__init__.py", line 19, in <module>
    from os_client_config import cloud_config
  File "/venv/python2_ansible24/lib/python2.7/site-packages/os_client_config/cloud_config.py", line 17, in <module>
    from openstack import _log
  File "/awx_devel/awx/plugins/inventory/openstack.py", line 67, in <module>
    import shade
  File "/venv/python2_ansible24/lib/python2.7/site-packages/shade/__init__.py", line 24, in <module>
    from shade.openstackcloud import OpenStackCloud
  File "/venv/python2_ansible24/lib/python2.7/site-packages/shade/openstackcloud.py", line 24, in <module>
    import os_client_config.defaults
  File "/venv/python2_ansible24/lib/python2.7/site-packages/os_client_config/defaults.py", line 17, in <module>
    from openstack.config import defaults
ImportError: No module named config
```

Note, if it had successfully imported, it could have been thrown in an infinite import loop.

This proposal is to pin as a top-level requirement

`os-client-config<=1.30.0`

Then we will have to deal with any patches needed for the script in a manual cherry-pick like process, if any such patches are needed.

the current script:

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/contrib/inventory/openstack_inventory.py

Our version, now diverging, of the script:

https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/awx/plugins/inventory/openstack.py

##### SUMMARY
Pushing job events into the database, in the callback receiver, is slow when a smart inventory is used. 

**Note:** Pushing events into rabbit is fast, pulling events from rabbit is fast. Events end up queued in run_callback_receiver subprocesses. It's nice to see that > 40k events can sit in our callback receiver waiting to be pushed into the database, no problem.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* Tower 3.4.1

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
* Create an inventory with at least 3,000 hosts
* Create 60 smart inventories that matches a fraction of those hosts, say 300.
* Run a playbook against any of the smart inventories.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
* Shortly after ansible job finishes, stdout shows in the UI

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
* job events take a *long* time to be processed (> 500 ms per event). This is observable in the UI/API

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
* Postgres queries taking =>~ 500 ms. Confirmed they are issued from callback receiver via strace.
`SELECT "main_host"."id", "main_host"."created", "main_host"."modified", "main_host"."description", "main_host"."created_by_id", "main_host"."modified_by_id", "main_host"."name", "main_host"."inventory_id", "main_host"."enabled", "main_host"."instance_id", "main_host"."variables", "main_host"."last_job_id", "main_host"."last_job_host_summary_id", "main_host"."has_active_failures", "main_host"."has_inventory_sources", "main_host"."ansible_facts", "main_host"."ansible_facts_modified", "main_host"."insights_system_id" FROM "main_host" WHERE ("main_host"."ansible_facts" @> '{"ansible_local": {"node": {"build": "beta"}}}' AND "main_host"."ansible_facts" @> '{"ansible_local": {"node": {"department": "engineering"}}}') ORDER BY "main_host"."name" ASC`

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Currently, if you have two jobs in a Workflow converging in one with RUN condition "On success", Tower runs the job if one of the previous one finishes successfully and not if both finish successfully. It would be great if you could set a RUN condition like "Run this convergent job just if these previous jobs finish successfully".

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Workflow example: 
![wfjt](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33290633/51599678-85fe3000-1f00-11e9-93a4-9432a6b38bf5.png)

In the example provided, "Job Template 1" and "Job Template 2" are set  with RUN condition "On success", but Tower runs "Job Tempate 3" if one of the previous jobs finishes successfully and not if both finish successfully.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
Similar to #1756, but in a simpler way.

Feature that will allow to schedule a job after completion of other scheduled job.
Many jobs can be scheduled after a certain job is completed. Scheduling can be done starting at some time.

Will help gluing many scheduled "environment dependent" workflows/jobs together .

Benefits are
 - No need for making of one big workflow in Workflow Editor with every prompt
 - Workflows are still "building blocks" but with scheduling capability to arrange them
 - User/Operator decides what to schedule without changing existing workflow or making a new ones

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
Currently it's possible to run simultaneously different jobs on single device which may cause problems.

This feature will forbid execution of 1 or more job on a single host/inventory.
* When inventory is specified whole inventory should locked for execution for execution of other jobs
* When hosts are specified separate hosts from inventory should be locked for execution of other jobs

Would also be great to see execution locks in UI.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY

We are triggering many concurrent jobs via a job template in AWX, using the API.  The job template includes a webhook notification to post the results back to the application that triggers the jobs.
However, some jobs' webhook notifications don't fire, despite the job completing (successfully or otherwise).  There is nothing obvious in the awx-task logs indicating a failure to send notifications for the jobs that do not send.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 2.1.2.0
* AWX install method: Kubernetes install via Ansible installer
* Ansible version:  2.7.4
* Operating System: CentOS Linux release 7.6.1810 (Core)  (Container)
* Web Browser: N/A

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

1.  Set up an https webhook notification on a job template, to send job results to some listener.
2.  Launch many jobs via the API endpoint "api/v2/job_templates/<templateid>/launch"

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

All jobs send notifications of their result, whether success or failure.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Not all jobs send notifications of their result.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

In the cases where no notifications are sent, the /jobs/<jobid>/notifications API endpoint contains no notifications, but this may just be because none were sent, i.e. this is not the cause, but an effect of the problem.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API
 - UI
 - Inventory

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem or desired enhancement. -->
This request was sort of posted under #2952, but was not properly described by the original poster (the RedHat support person who was trying to address my support case).  I'm reposting it here for clarity.

Hosts added to an inventory in Ansible Tower are automatically sorted by hostname.  When the order of the hosts matters (such as when using the order: keyword), this is a problem. Contrast this to Ansible Core where hosts in inventory files exist in the order specified by the author of the inventory.

As such, this enhancement request is to allow Ansible Tower inventories to have hosts listed in the order specified by the user. This would involve an option to disable the automatic sorting and perhaps a way to allow the user to drag hosts to reorder them within the inventory.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->

Here is a specific use case to help explain the need for this enhancement:

We have a set of servers; let's call them hq1, hq2, dr1, and dr2. They run proprietary software and the high availability (HA) works such that the flow of replication is hq1 -> hq2 -> dr1 -> dr2. In order to perform some maintenance operations, the HA needs to be disabled in reverse order (dr2, dr1, hq2, h1); this is where I want to use a play with `order: reverse_inventory`. The maintenance can then be performed on all hosts. Finally, HA needs to be enabled in forward order (hq1, hq2, dr1, dr2); this is where I want to use a play with `order: inventory` (the default).

When I create the inventory in Tower, the hosts get lexically ordered as dr1, dr2, hq1, hq2, which prevents the playbook from working as intended.

##### SUMMARY
I have workflow template with 9 job templates (JT), it has failed at JT-6. So I clicked on details on failed JT-6 due to a timeout in executing a task, so I relaunch the JT-6 by going into details and click relaunch button. It was successful after relaunch, however Ansible did not resume the workflow even after the failed JT-6s successful completion after rerun.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.4.0
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.6.4
* Operating System: Linux
* Web Browser: Chrome

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
1. Create a workflow template with more than 2 job templates and some extra variables in Survey
2. Have a failure condition in JT-2 on purpose
3. Launch the workflow template
4. Once JT-2 is failed,
5. Remove the failure condition from the playbook, so that when it be played next time it should run fine
6. Click on details on failed JT-2 from the workflow
7. Relaunch the JT-2 by clickin on launch button
8. JT-2 is successful now
9. Navigate back to the Workflow status page
10. Workflow still shows the JT-2 in failed state in Red colour, it wouldnt turn into Green
11. And workflow would not resume to execute the remianing JTs in the wokflow.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
Workflow should resume and complete all the JTs after rerunning the failed JT-2 successfully.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
Workflow gets stuck even after successful completion of a failed JT-2 upon rerun

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
This workflow is for application deployment, which consists of multiple steps, so i have created a JT for each task to identify which step failed. All these JTs are coded to run on a single host.
And the target host is a Windows Server 2012 R2

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
In working on https://github.com/ansible/awx/pull/2938 we on the UI team realized that it would be tremendously convenient for the job type to be present in job status socket messages.  It's particularly useful for the workflow results view where we need to build a static DETAILS link that would take the user out to the details of that particular job.  In the past, we've looked at the node's unified_job_type to do this but with the introduction of sjt's this is no longer enough information.  To get around this for now we've added a static redirect route which performs a GET request on the unified job and then redirects the user to the correct output view.  This solution could be removed if type were present in the message since we could use that to generate the link.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
Having an AWS dynamic inventory configured with

  - multiple inventory sources pointing to distinct AWS accounts
  - set `overwrite: true`
  - set `overwrite_vars: true`
  - set `update_on_launch: null`

Can result when updating all sources at once in a deadlock. For example when the update of all inventory source is triggered via `launch_type: callback`.

```
django.db.utils.OperationalError: deadlock detected
DETAIL:  Process 19431 waits for ShareLock on transaction 142021; blocked by process 19438.
Process 19438 waits for ShareLock on transaction 142022; blocked by process 19431.
HINT:  See server log for query details.
CONTEXT:  while deleting tuple (0,20) in relation "main_group_parents"
```
##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 2.x
* AWX install method: openshift, minishift, docker on linux, docker for mac, boot2docker
* Ansible version:  N/A
* Operating System: N/A
* Web Browser: N/A

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Configure AWS dynamic inventory with

  - multiple inventory sources pointing to distinct AWS accounts
  - set `overwrite: true`
  - set `overwrite_vars: true`
  - set `update_on_launch: null`

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

No deadlocks and successful updates from all inventory sources.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Deadlock during update of random inventory source in such inventory.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Here is a stripped down version of the playbook we are running

```
---
- hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: no

  vars_prompt:
    - name: vcenter_hostname
      prompt: "vCenter Host"
      private: no

    - name: vcenter_username
      prompt: "vCenter Username"
      private: no

    - name: vcenter_password
      prompt: "vCenter Password"
      private: yes

    - name: vm_name
      prompt: "Virtual Machine Name"
      private: no

    - name: vm_template
      prompt: "Virtul Machine Template"
      private: no

    - name: vm_folder
      prompt: "Virtual Machine Location Folder (sys.inf, sys.qa, datayard.local, sys.svc)"
      private: no

    - name: vm_memory
      prompt: "Virtual Machine Memory"
      private: no

    - name: vm_cpus
      prompt: "Virtual Machine CPU(s)"
      private: no

    - name: vm_datastore
      prompt: "Virtual Machine Datastore"
      private: no

    - name: vm_disksize
      prompt: "Virtual Machine Disk Size (GB)"
      private: no

    - name: vm_network
      prompt: "Virtual Machine Primary Network"
      private: no

    - name: vm_billingid
      prompt: "Billing ID"
      private: no

  tasks:
    - name: Create virtual machine from template
      vmware_guest:
          hostname: "{{ vcenter_hostname }}"
          username: "{{ vcenter_username }}"
          password: "{{ vcenter_password }}"
          validate_certs: no
          datacenter: Redacted
          esxi_hostname: Redacted
          folder: /Redacted/vm/{{ vm_folder }}
          name: "{{ vm_name }}"
          state: poweredon
          template: "{{ vm_template }}"
          customvalues: [
            {
              "key": "BillingID",
              "value": "{{ vm_billingid }}"
            }
          ]
          disk:
          - size_gb: "{{ vm_disksize }}"
            type: thin
            datastore: '[{{ vm_datastore }}]'
          hardware:
            memory_mb: "{{ vm_memory }}"
            num_cpus: "{{ vm_cpus }}"
            num_cpu_cores_per_socket: 1
            scsi: paravirtual
          networks:
            - name: "{{ vm_network }}"
              type: dhcp
              start_connected: true
          wait_for_ip_address: yes
      delegate_to: localhost
```

This playbook is working on a couple different systems, I've created a fresh ubuntu install with ansible 2.7.4, python 2.7.12, and pyvmomi 6.7.1 and experience no errors.

To experience this issue you do not need an active vcenter server, you'll get the error even if you put incorrect information in the variables 

pyvmomi version on awx is 6.5, we've tried upgrading this as well just as a test then reverted.

Any help would be greatly appreciated.
Thanks!

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Able to use an alternate version of python to setup a custom virtualenv.  

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem or desired enhancement. -->
We are using the HPE Oneview ansible modules (https://github.com/HewlettPackard/oneview-ansible) which require python 2.7.9 or higher.  The default python version in the AWX container (centos 7) is python 2.7.5.  

So to use the Oneview modules I installed Python 2.7.13 from Software Collections (https://wiki.centos.org/AdditionalResources/Repositories/SCL) inside the awx_task and awx_web containers.  This installs to /opt/rh/python27.  To enable this python you have to run:  

source /opt/rh/python27/enable

Now I can setup my virtualenv for the HPE Oneview modules.  

I've done this in both containers (task/web) and it accepts the virtualenv and displays it as a choice for my templates in AWX.  Once I try to run a job though I get symbol errors and it errors out.  As far as I can tell it's because AWX is not able to "enable" the newer version of python before running the job from the virtualenv.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->

Here's the steps I have done and the things I've done to try and make it work.  

These steps are done in both the awx_task and awx_web containers.

First install python 2.7.13:  

yum install scl-utils which
yum install centos-release-scl
yum clean all
yum install scl-utils-build python27.x86_64
vi /etc/yum.repos.d/CentOS-SCLo-scl.repo (disable repo)
vi /etc/yum.repos.d/CentOS-SCLo-scl-rh.repo (disable repo)
yum clean all

Now enable the new python version so that 2.7.13 is added to your PATH before the older OS python:

source /opt/rh/python27/enable

which python (/opt/rh/python27/root/usr/bin/python)
python -V (Python 2.7.13)

Now create the virtualenv:  

cd /var/lib/awx/venv
mkdir oneview_ansible265
which virtualenv (/opt/rh/python27/root/usr/bin/virtualenv)
virtualenv /var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265
cd oneview_ansible265
source bin/activate
which python (/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/bin/python)
python -V (Python 2.7.13)

Now install ansible and friends and also the HPE Oneview modules

which pip (/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/bin/pip)
pip install --upgrade pip
pip install --upgrade setuptools
pip install ansible==2.6.5
pip install hpOneView==4.7.0
pip install pyvmomi==6.7.1
pip install orionsdk==0.0.6

Okay now everything is installed. Repeat on the web container.  

Now in AWX I can select this custom_virtualenvs from the template page.  

When I run a job though, I get these symbol errors:  

Identity added: /tmp/awx_586_VnMs4j/credential_3 (/tmp/awx_586_VnMs4j/credential_3)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/bin/ansible-playbook", line 67, in <module>
    import ansible.constants as C
  File "/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ansible/constants.py", line 11, in <module>
    from jinja2 import Template
  File "/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/lib/python2.7/site-packages/jinja2/__init__.py", line 41, in <module>
    from jinja2.bccache import BytecodeCache, FileSystemBytecodeCache, \\
  File "/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/lib/python2.7/site-packages/jinja2/bccache.py", line 23, in <module>
    import tempfile
  File "/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/lib64/python2.7/tempfile.py", line 32, in <module>
    import io as _io
  File "/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/lib64/python2.7/io.py", line 51, in <module>
    import _io
ImportError: /var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/lib64/python2.7/lib-dynload/_io.so: undefined symbol: _PyErr_ReplaceException

If I login to the docker container I can do this:  

docker exec -it awx_task bash

Then...

cd venv/oneview_ansible265
source bin/activate
cd ../../projects/_10__my_project
ansible-playbook playbooks/site.yml
which python (/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/bin/python)
python -V (Python 2.7.5)

It's still trying to use the OS python v2.7.5...not the new Software Collections python installed in /opt.  

I get the same symbol errors.  

If I enable the new python version from Software Collections first though, it works properly (from inside the container anyway...not from AWX).  Logout and back in.

exit
docker exec -it awx_task bash
source /opt/rh/python27/enable 
cd venv/oneview_ansible265/
source bin/activate
cd ../../projects/_10__my_project
which python (/var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/bin/python)
python -V (Python 2.7.13)

Now it's using the new python and playbooks will run.  But this doesn't seem to be happening when AWX uses the virtualenv.  

Is there some way to get AWX to 'enable' the new python in /opt before it tries to use the virtualenv?  

I've tried to add the extra-var

ansible_python_interpreter: /var/lib/awx/venv/oneview_ansible265/bin/python2

to the template but it doesn't seem to help.  

I also wasn't sure how AWX was enabling the virtualenvs either.  Normally from the bash shell you run

source bin/activate

So I added this line to the top of that script

source /opt/rh/python27/enable

in hopes that AWX is also running 'source bin/activate'.  But this doesn't seem to help either.  There's also activate.csh and activate.fish but neither of those shells are installed in the container so I don't think they are used.  I also added this line to the activate_this.py script in case AWX was calling it:  

os.system('source /opt/rh/python27/enable')

but again, it doesn't seem to help.  

Any ideas on how we can use newer versions of python with virtualenvs in AWX?  

Thanks.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Parent WFJT Surveys apply extra_vars to child JTs, SJTs, and WFJTs in inconsistent ways.
- Child SJTs inherit Parent WFJT Surveys as extra_vars even if Child SJT has extra_var prompting disabled. Each slice inherits the surveys as extra_vars.
- Child JTs inherit Parent WFJT Surveys as extra_vars even if Child SJT has extra_var prompting disabled.
- Child WFJTs do not inherit Parent WFJT Surveys as extra_vars. "Grandchildren" do not inherit the extra_vars even if the extra_var prompt setting is enabled.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 3.4.0-workflow-inventory

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
1. Create a JT with extra_var prompting enabled. "JT A"
1. Create a JT with extra_var prompting disabled. "JT B"
1. Create a WFJT which contains both JT A and JT B. "Sub WFJT"
1. Create a WFJT which contains Sub WFJT, JT A, JT B. "Overall WFJT"
1. Modify "Overall WFJT" such that it contains survey values including a default value.
1. Run "Overall WFJT" and specify survey extra_vars or use default survey extra_vars.

Note: Sub WFJT and the grandchildren JT A and JT B are the only Jobs executed without inheriting the survey extra_vars.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
1. extra_var survey prompting should be observed in the same way regardless of Job Type.
1. extra_var surveys prompts should only apply to Jobs which have enabled extra_var prompting.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
Inconsistent application of extra_vars as surveys

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API


##### SUMMARY
Currently, once a user's session is expired it hangs around in the db indefinitely, or until the admin runs `awx-manage clearsessions` manually.  

This should default to clearing expired sessions once a week.  Additionally, expired OAuth2 access tokens should also be cleared out.  

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

This schedule could be added here: https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/awx/settings/defaults.py#L464

And the related tasks would have to be written in `tasks.py`.  


For cleaning up revoked oauth2 tokens, call this: https://github.com/jazzband/django-oauth-toolkit/blob/5b51da74019046ef4c8c81c9975db029a2113d52/oauth2_provider/models.py

##### ISSUE TYPE

##### SUMMARY
I have a playbook that works fine locally but when I put it in tower, it tells me a file doesn't exist, but it does. I added the path to "expose to isolated jobs" and I even tried turning off "enable job isolation" in tower but it still fails with same error. I assume its a permission thing, but I tried adding a few different things to my playbook including doing it all as root and still got the same result. That the file doesn't exist.  In tower I run my job template against localhost and I delegate to the node that has the tool installed that I need ran.

I reached out in ansible slack channel and the guy who helped me told me it was a bug so that is why I'm opening this.

I also thought maybe its tied to the mail module I'm trying to use.

##### ENVIRONMENT
Ansible Tower 3.2.1
Ansible version: ansible 2.4.0.0

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

run my playbook in ansible tower

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

I get an email with my results and csv files attached that I create in my ansible playbook

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Locally - it works
Tower - it says file doesn't exist.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

EXAMPLE OF MY PLAYBOOK (edited and shortened)

- name: run cipa on the node that has it installed and get details on prod
  delegate_to: '{{ delegate_host }}'
  environment:
    http_proxy: '{{ http_proxy_host }}'
    https_proxy: '{{ https_proxy_host }}'
  shell: cipa --no-border -H host, host, host, host, host -d ipa.domain.com -W '{{ dm_pw_prod }}' > /tmp/output_prod.csv
  register: cipa_output_prod_detailed
  tags: run_cipa_prod_detailed

- name: run cipa on the node that has it installed and get short details on prod
  delegate_to: '{{ delegate_host }}'

    http_proxy: '{{ http_proxy_host }}'
    https_proxy: '{{ https_proxy_host }}'

  failed_when: false
  no_log: true
  register: cipa_output_prod_short
  tags: run_cipa_prod_short


- name: email if fail is detected
  delegate_to: '{{ delegate_host }}'

    http_proxy: '{{ http_proxy_host }}'
    https_proxy: '{{ https_proxy_host }}'

    host: smtp.blah.com

      Please see attached csv file for more details

    secure: never

  tags: email_fail

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem or desired enhancement. -->
Allow mapping of SAML attributes to map to team and organization names that do not match attribute_value.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->
For example,

When mapping users with SAML attribute "ansibleOrganizations" and mapping attribute_value "developer-unix-org" to the organization "Unix Developers"
```json
{
    "saml_attr": "ansibleOrganizations",
    "saml_admin_attr": "ansibleOrganizationAdmins",
    "remove": true,
    "remove_admins": true,
    "org_map": [
    {
        "organization": "developer-unix-org",
        "org_alias": "Unix Developers"
    }
  ]
}
```

When mapping users with SAML attribute "ansibleGroups" and mapping attribute_value "unix-adms" to the team "Unix Administrators":
```json
{
    "saml_attr": "ansibleGroups",
    "remove": true,
    "team_org_map": [
    {
        "team": "unix-adms",
        "organization": "Default",
        "team_alias": "Unix Administrators"
    }
  ]
}
```

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
We use a custom script to import the inventory. The problem is that empty ansible groups are imported as `group` AND as `host`.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 2.0.1
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.7.1
* Operating System: Redhat
* Web Browser: Crome

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

- Set `CUSTOM_EXCLUDE_EMPTY_GROUPS = False` in `/etc/tower/settings.py` 
- Create a inventory file (ini)
```
[group-empty]
# None yet

[group-full]
host-1
```
- Create a inventory (from custom script)
- Source Script:
```
#!/bin/bash
ANSIBLE_INVENTORY_EXPORT=false ANSIBLE_CONFIG=/etc/ansible/ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_INVENTORY_ENABLED=ini,yaml,host_list,script,auto ansible-inventory -i /var/lib/awx/projects/io-ansible/prod --list --vault-password-file=/var/lib/awx/projects/io-ansible/vault_password.txt'
```
- Run the inventory import job

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

`group-empty` is imported as an empty group.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

`group-empty` is listed as group as well as an host (as host that belongs to the group). That causes issues during ansible playbook runs.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Looks similar to this issue:
https://github.com/ansible/awx/issues/1966

But setting only the flag does not work. If we add a sed command to add an empty host array, the import works as expected:

```
#!/bin/bash
ANSIBLE_INVENTORY_EXPORT=false ANSIBLE_CONFIG=/etc/ansible/ansible.cfg ANSIBLE_INVENTORY_ENABLED=ini,yaml,host_list,script,auto ansible-inventory -i /var/lib/awx/projects/io-ansible/prod --list --vault-password-file=/var/lib/awx/projects/io-ansible/vault_password.txt | sed -E 's/\{\}/\{\"hosts\": \[\]\}/g'
```

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Security Feature Request

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
In multi-tenant/multi-project environments, multiple administrators might have access to the same awx/tower host. The Inventory Script functionality is a known method of executing code and is used by awx-core for inventory management (per #ansible-awx freenode irc).

It would be helpful for more secure environments to differentiate between internal/core inventory scripts and user-provided scripts for the purpose of being able to disable the later.

A simple configuration 'allow_user_inventory_scripts' would be optimal (setting to False would prevent submitting/copying inventory scripts or using them within Inventories ("Custom Script").
This should hold true for UI or API usage.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
Tested and confirmed in Tower 3.3.1 and AWX 2.1.0.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - Installer

##### SUMMARY
By default, the logging driver is ```json-file``` and destroying a container will also remove logs. 
Changing it to ```journald``` for instance would allow us to access the logs of destroyed containers, on top of everything that is already possible with the default logging driver. In particular, the ```docker logs``` command remains available with ```journald``` (and only that one).
This feature can be made **optional** in ```installer/inventory``` with an option within the ```[all:vars]``` section:
```
logging_driver=journald
```
The user could even choose another logging driver such as ```syslog``` or ```splunk``` (the whole list of supported logging drivers is available [here](https://docs.docker.com/config/containers/logging/configure/#supported-logging-drivers)), if the user is notified somewhere that the ```docker logs``` command does NOT remain available for any other logging driver than ```journald```.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
This feature is enabled in the ```docker-compose.yml``` file for ```journald``` for instance with:
```
  web:
    logging:
        driver: journald
...
  task:
    logging:
        driver: journald
...
  rabbitmq:
    logging:
        driver: journald
...
  memcached:
    logging:
        driver: journald
...
  postgres:
    logging:
        driver: journald
...
```
The last entry depends on whether postgresql server is internal or external.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
If we set timeout to the job template and launch it and when it failed with the timeout error, we can confirm the cause of this from the `job_explanation` value from the Jobs API endpoint, but there is no way to confirm it from log files.
Also even if we use logging aggregation, there is no information about this timeout error and It would be ideal to more easily identify the cause of job failure are currently being acted upon.

It would be ideal to more easily identify the cause of job failure are currently being acted upon from Tower's local logs and external logging aggregation system.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

I think it would be better if we can add an `rc` for these jobs, Or we can append `job_explanation` to the logs that we export to the external logging aggregators.

##### SUMMARY
Currently, when adding a new user (and across other form fields where character maximums are only passively reinforced), you can flood the text field with characters, but then an error message appears after creating the user fails:

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Need the ability to create a smart inventory based on regular expression

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
A common practice is to use a standardized hostname for nodes in an inventory. A regular expression can be used against some attribute (like inventory_hostname) to have dynamically created groups. A use case would be for bootstrapping of a node. 

Consider the following workflow:
- An admin could provision a node 'devweb01'
- The node is added to Ansible Tower's inventory through the dynamic inventory
- The node is automatically added to the group development_webservers because it matches the regular expression associated with that group
- Ansible configures the node with appropriate roles and variable due to its presence in the development_webservers group

##### ISSUE TYPE
- The current UI makes it difficult to track variables set on GROUPS in an INVENTORY. It would be helpful if groups were presented as a tree to visualize group and subgroup relationships.

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
 Ansible Tower allows the user to create groups and associate groups with other groups from the UI. It is difficult to track down a nodes variables when it belongs to multiple groups. For example if I have a group called 'linux' and multiple sub-groups below that with overriding variables it is difficult to tell which groups are subgroups of 'linux' which would inherit any variable set on the 'linux' group. A current workaround is to put the parent names in the name of the group( ie linux_webservers). This becomes even more challenging at more than 2 levels of groups.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - UI


##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem or desired enhancement. -->
When you import roles into AWX, you need to run the playbook that calls each role. The result is that every roles output is displayed in the stdout window.

It would be great if we could take all roles under the `roles:` heading and split them into Workflows. This would provide a more user friendly experience and make troubleshooting much easier.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->
If we look at the role deployment file:
~~~
- hosts: status_up 
  become: True
  become_method: sudo
  vars_files:
    - base_config/vars/main.yml
    - ntp_clients/vars/main.yml
    - snmp_hosts/vars/main.yml
    - zabbix_clients/vars/main.yml

  roles:
    - foreman_clients
    - base_config
    - ntp_clients
    - snmp_hosts
    - zabbix_clients
~~~

We can see that this playbook calls the roles specified under `roles:`

If I manually break them up into individual playbooks, I'm able to create a workflow within AWX that looks much better:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5205987/47397302-02526d00-d772-11e8-8b93-3bb87a16b8a9.png)


If we could provide the user with an option to do this within the UI. I believe it would improve user experience with AWX.

- disable instances
- wait for jobs to drain
- hope new ones don't get submitted
- once done, shut it down (for upgrades, etc.)

Ideally, there is a "one-stop" option for draining a cluster, that *also* involves not letting new jobs be submitted in the interim.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
Be able to convert user authentication method from UI after migrating the user that is authenticating via AD/LDAP from old AWX instance to new AWX instance.

- when you sync a user that is authenticating via AD/LDAP using tower-cli from one instance to another and that user don't exists on the destination instance the user will be sync but created as local user with default password. We need a feature that could convert that user back to authenticating via AD/LDAP without deleting it so that there permission on the other assets are retained.

- create something like a drop down field in the user details section (like the USER TYPE drop down) to choose the AUTHENTICATION TYPE either local or the current external authentication that is configured in AWX.

##### SUMMARY
Inside of the job serialization, mark these files for eventual removal:

```json
            "ask_diff_mode_on_launch": false,
            "ask_variables_on_launch": false,
            "ask_limit_on_launch": false,
            "ask_tags_on_launch": false,

            "ask_verbosity_on_launch": false,
            "ask_inventory_on_launch": false,
            "ask_credential_on_launch": false,
```

(9 fields)

The implementation of these looks like:

https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/5910b8c5627d46ad52a41801c6998322973c650e/awx/main/models/jobs.py#L548-L552

I believe there is a good case to say that these don't provide any real value. They just add confusion.

job serialization in list:

https://gist.github.com/AlanCoding/f0ac97a46c6388285d26e47894f97279

It takes 88 lines for the job's serialization, so 9 lines, about 10% isn't nothing.

@ryanpetrello since these have been around for a while, I think there's a good case to mark them as deprecated, but still wait until API v3 to actually remove them. Interested in your thoughts on that.

##### SUMMARY
Add functionality to manage a predefined list of inventories in a job template.  This would limit the inventories in which a job template can be executed.

In a organization/group with a large number of inventories which cannot be more limited by RBAC, this feature would help to speed up the "inventory selection" process during the execution as well as avoid possible mistakes caused by selecting the wrong inventory.

```
class NotificationTemplateTest(GenericAPIView):
    '''Test a Notification Template'''

    view_name = _('Notification Template Test')
    model = NotificationTemplate
    obj_permission_type = 'start'
    serializer_class = EmptySerializer

    def post(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
        obj = self.get_object()
        notification = obj.generate_notification("Tower Notification Test {} {}".format(obj.id, settings.TOWER_URL_BASE),
                                                 {"body": "Ansible Tower Test Notification {} {}".format(obj.id, settings.TOWER_URL_BASE)})
        if not notification:
            return Response({}, status=status.HTTP_400_BAD_REQUEST)
        else:
            connection.on_commit(lambda: send_notifications.delay([notification.id]))
            data = OrderedDict()
            data['notification'] = notification.id
            data.update(NotificationSerializer(notification, context=self.get_serializer_context()).to_representation(notification))
            headers = {'Location': notification.get_absolute_url(request=request)}
            return Response(data,
                            headers=headers,
                            status=status.HTTP_202_ACCEPTED)
```

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Here's a unit test to haphazardly create a table of what works and doesn't work:

```python
@pytest.mark.django_db
def test_vars_consistency(patch, inventory, job_template, project, wfjt_node, admin_user):
    d = {'foo': 'bar'}
    job_template.project = project
    job_template.ask_variables_on_launch = True
    job_template.ask_inventory_on_launch = True
    job_template.inventory = inventory
    job_template.playbook = 'helloworld.yml'
    job_template.save()
    for kind, vars in (('dict', d), ('json_str', json.dumps(d)), ('yaml_str', 'foo: bar')):
        print ''
        print ' testing kind: ' + str(kind)
        for res, fd in ((inventory, 'variables'), (job_template, 'extra_vars'), (wfjt_node, 'extra_data')):
            print ' field: ' + str(fd)
            try:
                patch(
                    url=res.get_absolute_url(),
                    data={fd: vars},
                    user=admin_user,
                    expect=200
                )
                print ' worked '
            except Exception as e:
                print ' did not work ' + str(e)
    assert False
```

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

All fields accept all forms of passing the variables in.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

table from those results

| field \ accepts           | plain dict | JSON string | YAML string |
|---------------------------|------------|-------------|-------------|
| inventory (variables)     |           |            |            |
| job template (extra_vars) |           |            |            |
| WFJT nodes (extra_data)   |           |            |            |

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Also, job template `extra_vars` will preserve comments, while none of the others will.

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem. -->
I set up a Git repo under my work email with one .yml file as a playbook.  Set up a new project named 'Test Repo' in AWX.  That file named createfile.yml shows up when I try to create a new job template using that project.  However, any new files added to the Git repo are not showing up in AWX.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
We should give a 400 message if a user tries to use "ANSIBLE_" environment variables in a custom credential type. See:

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible-tower/latest/html/userguide/credential_types.html

> Also, avoid environment variable or extra variable names that start with ANSIBLE_ because they are reserved.

It's not obvious what the actual behavior in this case is, but I believe that they are ignored.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Job relaunch has something weird happening when the JT credentials have changed since the prior launch

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.8
* AWX install method: openshift, minishift, docker on linux, docker for mac, boot2docker
* Ansible version:  X.Y.Z
* Operating System:
* Web Browser:

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

 - Create a new custom credential type
 - create 2 credentials of this type
 - launch a JT using the first of those credentials (not a prompt, on the JT)
 - modify JT to use 2nd of those credentials
 - relaunch the first job

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

relaunched job has 2nd credential

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

relaunched job has both credentials (note: they are of same type, which is a violation of our rules).

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
There is no way to tell at a glance if a project update actually detected any change in the repo that it syncs. It would be nice to show this information.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

The API currently doesn't deliver this info on the project update level. Even the playbook output doesn't give this information.

Put in terms of git, my question for the API is: "when you ran the update, did you find any new commits?"

suggested icon:

##### SUMMARY

From https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.6/scenario_guides/guide_azure.html#providing-credentials-to-azure-modules:

...

Using Environment Variables

To pass service principal credentials via the environment, define the following variables:

    AZURE_CLIENT_ID
    AZURE_SECRET
    AZURE_SUBSCRIPTION_ID
    AZURE_TENANT

To pass Active Directory username/password via the environment, define the following variables:

    AZURE_AD_USER
    AZURE_PASSWORD

To pass Active Directory username/password in ADFS via the environment, define the following variables:

    AZURE_AD_USER
    AZURE_PASSWORD
    AZURE_CLIENT_ID
    AZURE_TENANT
    AZURE_ADFS_AUTHORITY_URL

AZURE_ADFS_AUTHORITY_URL is optional. Its necessary only when you have own ADFS authority like https://xxx.com/adfs.
...

We do not support all of these in the current Azure credential.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
OAuth2 tokens having an expiration date in the past should be automatically deleted. 
A token listing can be retrieved by a GET request for /api/v2/tokens/
The list of tokens currently contains active and expired tokens but should show active tokens only.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.6
* AWX install method: docker
* Ansible version:  2.5.4
* Operating System: CentOS Linux 7.5.2804
* Web Browser: Google Chrome 68.0.3440.106

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
1. Update the value of ACCESS_TOKEN_EXPIRE_SECONDS from 31536000000 to 1200 by sending a PATCH request to /api/v2/settings/authentication/ (body: updated result of the GET request to /api/v2/settings/authentication/).
2. Create a token by sending a POST request to /api/v2/tokens/ having the following body: {"description": "My Access Token","scope": "write"}
3. Wait half an hour or more.
4. List all tokens by sending a GET request to /api/v2/tokens/
5. The expired token is present in the list of tokens.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

The list of tokens shows all tokens (active and expired). Expired tokens are never deleted.

I can delete the expired token by sending a DELETE request to /api/v2/tokens/{id}/ but this should not be necessary in my opinion.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Some resources can be created via a POST to their list view.

Some resources can be created via a POST to a sublist of another (parent-like) resource.

Some can be created by both methods.

It's impossible to predict which will be the case.

We should change this so clients can create via POST in all global lists and parent-like sublists.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

As an example, go to `/api/v2/schedules/` and observe that you cannot create a schedule from this view, even as superuser. This causes headaches, such as https://github.com/ansible/tower-cli/issues/578

At a cursory glance, it seems like a reasonable API practice because "I can't create a schedule unless I already have a template". But credentials / credential types go in the exact opposite direction. See a few highlight examples:

| resource           | parent resource | global creation | sublist creation |
|--------------------|-----------------|-----------------|------------------|
| project            | organization    | yes             | yes              |
| inventory          | organization    | yes             | no               |
| host / group / src | inventory       | yes             | yes              |
| schedule           | template        | no              | yes              |
| credential         | credential type | yes             | no               |

Idea here is that all of these would flip to "yes"

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Add an option in the configuration to limit the maximum verbosity allowed for a job template within the organization.  This will limit the volume of data placed in the database for each run, and therefore, limit the overall size and associated performance and operational impacts.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem or desired enhancement. -->

If we have a huge workflow with multiple branches. Currently, there is no way to move or delete 1 complete branch in one shot. We have to remove all the job nodes 1 by 1.  
It is very time-consuming & error prone process.

There should be an option to remove any branch from START in one shot. 
Also we should be able to move any branch from anywhere and connect with any other node in any branch.

 - UI

##### SUMMARY

##### SUMMARY
AWX now populates all the available venvs to all the users, we would like to restrict it based onorganization's assigned venv. 

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.4
* AWX install method: openshift
* Ansible version:  2.6.3
* Operating System: CentOS
* Web Browser: google chrome

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

1. Create a new venv as described in the page https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/docs/custom_virtualenvs.md
2. Assign newly created venv to any of the existing org and logout as admin user.
3. Login as a member of the org to which venv was assigned.
4. Create a new job template (for example) and select the dropdown to choose virtual environment. User will be able to see all the venvs not just the ones assigned to the org.

Ideally I would expect only assigned venv to pop up in the dropdown.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Ideally I would expect only assigned venv to pop up in the dropdown.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

All the venvs are listed in the dropdown.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
NA

* AWX version: 1.0.7.3

Stop the database (or add iptables rule to deny access from celery).

The connection to the database must be restored

The connection to the database is not restored

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Notifications should have option to include job output as attachment (plain/html) or inline with body. I maintain a very clean template UI for users who only need to run workflow templates. I don't grant these users access to the underlying templates. As such these are hidden from the Templates and Jobs tab. These users can't view the output of failed jobs. If I could include job output of a failed playbook in the notification, I can maintain a clean Template UI.

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem. -->
- No logging when debugging AD authentication issues on Ubuntu 18.04.1 - AWX 1.0.7.2

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.7.2
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.6.2 
* Operating System: Ubuntu 18.04
* Web Browser: Safari, Firefox

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

<!-- For bugs, please show exactly how to reproduce the problem. For new
features, show how the feature would be used.  -->

`/etc/tower/conf.d/ldap.py` created
`LOGGING['handlers']['tower_warnings']['level'] =  'DEBUG'` added to ldap.py

LDAP Config:
```
Server URL
ldaps://<LDAP Server>:636

Bind DN
CN=ansible,CN=users,DC=<LDAP domain>,DC=com

LDAP User Search
[
 "OU=Users,DC=<LDAP domain>,DC=com",
 "SCOPE_SUBTREE",
 "(cn=%(user)s)"
]

LDSP Group Search
[
 "dc=<LDAP domain>,dc=com",
 "SCOPE_SUBTREE",
 "(objectClass=group)"
]

LDAP User Attribute MAP
{
 "first_name": "givenName",
 "last_name": "sn",
 "email": "mail"
}

LDSP Group Type Params
{
 "member_attr": "member",
 "name_attr": "cn"
}

LDSP User Flags by Group
{
 "is_superuser": [
  "cn=AWX Admin,ou=groups,dc=<LDAP domain>,dc=com"
 ]
}

LDAP Org MAP
{
 "MAIN": {
  "users": [
   "cn=AWX Users,ou=groups,dc=<LDAP domain>,dc=com"
  ],
  "admins": "cn=AWX Admin,ou=groups,dc=<LDAP domain>,dc=com",
  "remove_admins": false,
  "remove_users": false
 }
}
```
##### EXPECTED RESULTS

<!-- For bug reports, what did you expect to happen when running the steps
above? -->

Failures logged into `/var/log/tower`

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

<!-- For bug reports, what actually happened? -->
No logging exists on failed login with AD accounts

 - Feature Idea

 - API
 - UI
 - Installer

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem or desired enhancement. -->
It would be useful to be able to manage Satellite via playbook tasks. AWX currently does not include injectors for the Satellite 6 credential, meaning they are not usable in a playbook. 

When creating a custom credential, these are the injectors used:
```yaml
injectors:
      extra_vars:
        satellite_username: "{{ '{{ \"{{username}}\" }}'}}"
        satellite_password: "{{ '{{ \"{{password}}\" }}'}}"
        satellite_host: "{{ '{{ \"{{host}}\" }}'}}"
```

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
"check" type project updates check out the full source tree to the file system.

This is not necessary, and it will be done on the pre-JT sync anyway. It would be lazier behavior, and more performant, to avoid this in the updates themselves.

It would also be semantically more easy to understand that a "check" type update just checks.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: all
* AWX install method: openshift, minishift, docker on linux, docker for mac, boot2docker
* Ansible version:  X.Y.Z
* Operating System:
* Web Browser:

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Create a project, check the projects folder. Alternatively, delete the project folder and do a new update, or update the project and do a new update.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

source tree checkout is lazy, so the source tree should not be there after just creating the project, or be unaffected by the update.

The server should wait until actually running a job before checking out the source tree.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Every project update clones the full source tree

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

the git module clearly has utilities to accomplish this:

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/0a701ff74601748efa93fbc366e6368e53c39cd0/lib/ansible/modules/source_control/git.py#L494-L534

examples using git CLI:

```
$ git ls-remote https://github.com/ansible/ansible.git -h HEAD
8662e87b1af9b189d9c10d80655581807ad520dc	HEAD
$ git ls-remote https://github.com/ansible/ansible.git -h refs/heads/stable-2.3
b20520f500ad6878750bd2e2e8be46f756e4eaa5	refs/heads/stable-2.3
```

it appears that we can _just_ use these utilities without actually checking out if we use check_mode

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/0a701ff74601748efa93fbc366e6368e53c39cd0/lib/ansible/modules/source_control/git.py#L1067-L1074

So this is entirely possible...

but a major challenge will be how we deal with populating the playbook list.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY

Currently :
 -  `extra_vars` are allowed for Nodes within workflows(job_template). Only vars defined in survey can be used here in extra_vars.
 -  `extra_data` variables are allowed for whole job_template/workflow only.

This is a suggestion of adding a support for `extra_data` within workflow on per-workflow node(job_template) basis. This will allow more precise control of workflow job_templates.

##### SUMMARY
When using set_stats, callback is not written. An error is generated, but playbook run successfully. Subsequent playbook in a workflow template does not receive set_stats on execution.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
awx/lib/awx_display_callback/module.py

##### ANSIBLE VERSION
```
ansible-playbook 2.6.1
  config file = /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg
  configured module search path = [u'/var/lib/awx/.ansible/plugins/modules', u'/usr/share/ansible/plugins/modules']
  ansible python module location = /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ansible
  executable location = /usr/bin/ansible-playbook
  python version = 2.7.5 (default, Feb 20 2018, 09:19:12) [GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-28)]
Using /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg as config file
```

##### OS / ENVIRONMENT
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 7.4 (Maipo)  
Ansible Tower 3.2.5 
Ansible 2.6.1

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
```yaml
---
- hosts: tower
  become: no
  gather_facts: no

  tasks:
  - set_stats:
      data:
        extra_vars:
          some_fact: 'foo'
        some_fact: 'foo'
```

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
```
CUSTOM STATS: ******************************************************************

	RUN: { "extra_vars": {  "some_fact": "foo" },  "some_fact": "foo"}
```


##### ACTUAL RESULTS
```
 [WARNING]: Failure using method (v2_playbook_on_stats) in callback plugin
(<awx_display_callback.module.AWXDefaultCallbackModule object at
0x7fa9b563bf10>): [Errno 17] File exists:
'/var/lib/awx/.ansible/tmp/awx_3094_b7FWcd/artifacts'

Callback Exception: 
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ansible/executor/task_queue_manager.py", line 374, in send_callback
    method(*new_args, **kwargs)
   File "/lib/python2.7/site-packages/awx/lib/awx_display_callback/module.py", line 323, in v2_playbook_on_stats
   File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/os.py", line 157, in makedirs
    mkdir(name, mode)
```

##### CODE TO BLAME
https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/awx/lib/awx_display_callback/module.py#L311

( last line in block below)
```
        if custom_artifact_data:
            # create the directory for custom stats artifacts to live in (if it doesn't exist)
            custom_artifacts_dir = os.path.join(os.getenv('AWX_PRIVATE_DATA_DIR'), 'artifacts')
            os.makedirs(custom_artifacts_dir, mode=stat.S_IXUSR + stat.S_IWUSR + stat.S_IRUSR)
```
It appears that on an isolated node, the custom_artifact_dir is automatically created. Add if condition to os.makedirs fixes the observed behavior:



```
        if custom_artifact_data:
            # create the directory for custom stats artifacts to live in (if it doesn't exist)
            custom_artifacts_dir = os.path.join(os.getenv('AWX_PRIVATE_DATA_DIR'), 'artifacts')
            if not os.path.isdir(custom_artifacts_dir):
                os.makedirs(custom_artifacts_dir, mode=stat.S_IXUSR + stat.S_IWUSR + stat.S_IRUSR)
```

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Inventory updates have log-based verbosity, `ansible-inventory` has verbosity too, but the latter has no bearing on the former. We should change that.

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

run an inventory update and crank the verbosity up as far as it goes

raise an exception in the script it runs

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

traceback from exception

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

no traceback

we can get traceback by converting our inventory update verbosity to ansible verbosity (`-v`, `-vv`, etc.) and passing that in CLI args.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

This could introduce problems if, in some cases, Ansible core writes verbose information to stdout, causing the JSON parser to error.

Does not exist
