##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
I use AWX Project synced with a Git repository with SSH source control credential type which uses a private key and a passphrase.
Everything's fine except if I try to sync the AWX Project with a different branch than the default branch of the Git repository e.g: using the "SCM BRANCH/TAG/COMMIT" field in the AWX Project configuration. In this use case the project sync job launches the command "/usr/bin/git ls-remote origin -h refs/heads/mybranch" after clonging the repository branch. And this command apparently fails to authenticate through SSH with the private key and passphrase.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.6.3
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.5.2
* Operating System: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS
* Web Browser: Google Chrome 67.0.3396.99 (Official Build) (64-bit)

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
- We want to sync an AWX project with a specific branch of Git (Gitlab in my case) repository. The authentication method to git is SSH with private key and passphrase.
- Create a credential of type "Source Control" with:
  - a username ("git") in my case
  - no password
  - a private key and its passphrase
- Create an AWX Project with:
  - "SCM Type" set to "Git" and sync it with a repository
  - "SCM Credential" set to the previously created "Source Control" credential
  - "SCM BRANCH/TAG/COMMIT" set to a branch different from the default clone branch of the Git repository, lets call it "mybranch"
- Save the project click on the button "Get latest SCM revision" to get the project from the Git repository

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
The project is successfully synced and exists in /var/lib/awx/project directory inside the awx_task_1 Docker container.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
The Project sync job fails with the following error:
```
fatal: [localhost]: FAILED! => 
{
   "changed":false,
   "cmd":"/usr/bin/git ls-remote origin -h refs/heads/mybranch",
   "msg":"ssh: connect to host gitlab.mydomain.com port 22: Connection refused\\r\\nfatal: Could not read from remote repository.\\n\\nPlease make sure you have the correct access rights\\nand the repository exists.",
   "rc":128,
   "stderr":"ssh: connect to host gitlab.mydomain.com port 22: Connection refused\\r\\nfatal: Could not read from remote repository.\\n\\nPlease make sure you have the correct access rights\\nand the repository exists.\\n",
   "stderr_lines":[
      "ssh: connect to host gitlab.mydomain.com port 22: Connection refused",
      "fatal: Could not read from remote repository.",
      "",
      "Please make sure you have the correct access rights",
      "and the repository exists."
   ],
   "stdout":"",
   "stdout_lines":[

   ]
}
```
However:
- The project actually exists inside `/var/lib/awx/project/_X__myproject`
- a `git status` inside `/var/lib/awx/project/_X__myproject` reports that:
```
On branch mybranch
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/mybranch'.

nothing to commit, working tree clean
```

So as stated in my brief summary, the clone was done successfully but the command "/usr/bin/git ls-remote origin -h refs/heads/mybranch" apparently fails to authenticate through SSH with the private key and passphrase.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
This is a minor issue ihmo because if I leave the "SCM BRANCH/TAG/COMMIT" field empty in the Project configuration then everything goes fine. So as a workaround, I simply changed the default branch of my repository from "master" to "mybranch".
However @matburt on IRC told me I could file the issue here.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Django's base class seems to allow for a `timeout` parameter for the email notification class, but AWX doesn't allow making use of it

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: any
* AWX install method: openshift, minishift, docker on linux, docker for mac, boot2docker
* Ansible version:  X.Y.Z
* Operating System:
* Web Browser:

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Send a notification with incorrect configuration, see how long it takes to get a connection refused error

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Some way to configure timeout

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

It could be system-dependent, but through experimentation I can see a difference between an attempt to send the email notification to when it errors of 12:34:37 to 12:38:21, or around 4 minutes total.

Hypothetically. being a rational actor, and not wanting to swamp my system in the case my flaky email server sometimes dies, I would like the timeout to be shorter.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Our class:

https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/awx/main/notifications/email_backend.py

The base class of that:

https://github.com/django/django/blob/stable/1.11.x/django/core/mail/backends/smtp.py

This allows a `timeout` parameter that users can't make use of... yet.

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem. -->
When running a job template which launches a project update and the project update is pulling roles down from a requirements.yml file the output in the Tower job reports:
 | 49 | TASK [Write Repository Version] ************************************************ | 16:32:13
 | 50 | changed: [localhost] | 
 | 51 |  | 
 | 52 | PLAY [all] ********************************************************************* | 16:32:13
 | 53 |  | 
 | 54 | TASK [detect requirements.yml] ************************************************* | 16:32:13
 | 55 | skipping: [localhost] | 
 | 56 |  | 
 | 57 | TASK [fetch galaxy roles from requirements.yml] ******************************** | 16:32:13
 | 58 | skipping: [localhost] | 
 | 59 |  | 
 | 60 | TASK [fetch galaxy roles from requirements.yml (forced update)] **************** | 16:32:14
 | 61 | skipping: [localhost] | 
 | 62 |  | 
 | 63 | PLAY RECAP *********************************************************************

Note the skipping:[localhost].

However, if you check /var/lib/awx/project/_<id>__<project name>/roles/ the roles files will be there.


##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.6.3
* AWX install method: docker for mac
* Ansible version:  2.6.1
* Operating System: OS X
* Web Browser: Any

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

<!-- For bugs, please show exactly how to reproduce the problem. For new
features, show how the feature would be used.  -->
The JSON mentioned below will build a project called GIT Project and a job template called GIT Test. The project will be tied to Default organization tied back to a public GHE repo of mine. The JT will be tied to the GIT Project and Demo Inventory running a playbook called get_ip.yml which just spits out ansible_default_ipv4.address in a debug statement.

Here is the import command (just make sure you dont already have a GIT Project or GIT Test JT):
tower-cli send tower-host XXXX git_stuff.json 
If you run into any issues be sure you have a github version of tower-cli. 

Once its imported check out /var/lib/awx/projects/_<ID>__git_project/roles and note that thee is only a requirements.yml file. Now kick off the GIT Test job, this will kick off a full SCM update of GIT Project. It should then create /var/lib/awx/projects/_<ID>__git_projects/roles/yatesr.timezone
Now look at project update job in Tower, scroll down to the bottom. You should see the skipping label.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

<!-- For bug reports, what did you expect to happen when running the steps
above? -->
If the steps are truly skipping I would expect that the yatesr.timezone directory would not exist. However, I expect the labels to not say skipping, instead they should correctly report changed or OK.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
The logs indicate that the role steps are skipping.
<!-- For bug reports, what actually happened? -->

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other

The job should fail since the isolated node is unreachable.

The job remains in running status indefinitely instead of fails.

##### SUMMARY
I have an issue with a job launch template via the API call.
When you cURL a json template with survey **list** variable it is ignored.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.6.11
* AWX install method: docker
* Ansible version:  2.5.3
* Operating System: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS
* Web Browser: Firefox 61.0.1 (64-bit)

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
Create a job template with survey and a multiple selection list.
Then `curl -L -X POST "http://awx_host/api/v2/job_templates/job_id/launch" -d @awx-config.json -H "Content-Type: application/json" -H "Authorization: Basic YourAUTH"`
awx-config.json below
`{
 "extra_vars": {
  "list1": [
   "item1",
   "item2"
  ],
  "list2": [
   "item3",
   "item4"
  ],
  "var1": "bar1",
  "var2": "bar2"
 }
}`

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

List values should be updated from the json body.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

When template is running on the role I only get the **var1** and **var2** changed vars.
**List1** and **List2** remain the default values of the survey.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report
 

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
Attempting to log on with a LDAP user simply logs a 401 error. Logging in with a locally defined user works.

- "POST /api/login/ HTTP/1.1" 401 5879 "https://host.domain.com/" "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_13_5) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/11.1.1 Safari/605.1.15"

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.6.25
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  version included in docker container
* Operating System: RHEL7
* Web Browser: Safari

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Configure LDAP: (obviously changed sensitive information)

"AUTH_LDAP_SERVER_URI": "ldap://controller.domain.com:389",
    "AUTH_LDAP_BIND_DN": "CN=awxuser,OU=Users,DC=domain,DC=com",
    "AUTH_LDAP_BIND_PASSWORD": [password],
    "AUTH_LDAP_START_TLS": false,
    "AUTH_LDAP_CONNECTION_OPTIONS": {
        "OPT_NETWORK_TIMEOUT": 30,
        "OPT_REFERRALS": 0
    },
    "AUTH_LDAP_USER_SEARCH": ["OU=Users,DC=domain,DC=com","SCOPE_SUBTREE","(cn=%(user)s)"],
    "AUTH_LDAP_USER_DN_TEMPLATE": "",
    "AUTH_LDAP_USER_ATTR_MAP": {},
    "AUTH_LDAP_GROUP_SEARCH": ["OU=Groups,dc=domain,dc=com","SCOPE_SUBTREE","(objectClass=group)"],
    "AUTH_LDAP_GROUP_TYPE": "ActiveDirectoryGroupType",
    "AUTH_LDAP_GROUP_TYPE_PARAMS": {},
    "AUTH_LDAP_REQUIRE_GROUP": null,
    "AUTH_LDAP_DENY_GROUP": null,
    "AUTH_LDAP_USER_FLAGS_BY_GROUP": {"is_superuser": "CN=admins,OU=Groups,DC=domain,dc=com"},

Login via UI with LDAP user.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Access should be granted

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

"POST /api/login/ HTTP/1.1" 401 5879 "https://host.domain.com/" "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_13_5) AppleWebKit/605.1.15 (KHTML, like Gecko) Version/11.1.1 Safari/605.1.15"

UI displays - Invalid username and/or password. Please try again.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Add a restrictive Content-Security-Policy (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP) to awx to drastically reduce the surface area for a wide variety of in-browser security issues.

This is **really easy** to do on the backend:

```python
response['Content-Security-Policy'] = "default-src 'self'; report-uri /csp-violation/"
```

It's _hard_ on the front-end, because we'd need to identify any place we (or third-party libraries) inject inline JS and CSS.

Current roadblocks **may** include:

* Our version of Angular _itself_ (need to read up on https://code.angularjs.org/1.6.10/docs/api/ng/directive/ngCsp) 
* https://github.com/josdejong/mathjs/issues/401 (used by the network UI - it sounds like we're only using one or two small functions from this dependency, so maybe we can just lose it entirely?)
* Anything related to the pendo service?

##### SUMMARY
1. Make an awx-command for revoking all OAuth2 tokens.
2. Add an optional `--user` flag to revoke a single user's OAuth2 tokens
3. Make an optional `--revoke_refresh` flag to also revoke the associated refresh token

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

```
# The following command should revoke all existing OAuth2 Tokens 
$ awx-manage revoke_tokens

# The following command should revoke all OAuth2 Tokens & their refresh tokens
$ awx-manage revoke_tokens --revoke_refresh

# The following command should revoke all OAuth2 Tokens for the user with id=<pk>. 
$ awx-manage revoke_tokens --user=<pk>

# The following command should revoke all OAuth2 Tokens & refresh token for the user with id=<pk>. 
$ awx-manage revoke_tokens --user=<pk> --revoke_refresh

# <pk-dne> is an user that does not exist.

CommandError: The user does not exist.
```

##### SUMMARY
Unnecessary projects' directories should be removed.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.2.74
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version: 2.4.2.0
* Operating System: Ubuntu 16.04
* Web Browser:

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
- Create a project
- Do SCM update
- Delete the project
<!-- For bugs, please show exactly how to reproduce the problem. For new
features, show how the feature would be used.  -->

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
There are no files related to removed project in root directory (`/var/lib/awx/projects`)

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
The files still there
<!-- For bug reports, what actually happened? -->

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
The main problem is extremely fast exhaustion of disk free space when AWX is intensively used and project's repositories are heavy.
The situation is getting worse when you will try cleanup old files by yourself. It's hard to determine which files in use right now and which free for removing even using AWX API.
Probably we need some indexing of directories to relate it with AWX internal objects and some kind of garbage collector (a management job?) which will purge orphans files. 
<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->

It would be beneficial to have the ability to rename jobs in AWX.  For something with a long survey, it would be useful to be able to quickly get access to and rerun the job with the same parameters.

You can't do this with labels, because you can only add labels at the jt level, not the job (and thus the populated-with-particular-survey-based-extra-vars value can't be different by them)

The closest thing you can do is search for the template or the jobs that are `created_by:you` and remember when you last ran the job, which works, but is kind of a finicky flow.

There isn't a "detail" form-based view for jobs, so this is dependent on some sort of ux concept for inline-editing flow, a rename modal, something else?

Also would need to be able to PUT the new job name to the API.

##### SUMMARY
Some external loggers will intermittently reject some attempts to send log messages. We need a retry logic in order to fully solve this. It might be a simple if the fix is specific to Splunk, otherwise, we may need to utilize our messaging system to process logs.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: any
* AWX install method: openshift, minishift, docker on linux, docker for mac, boot2docker
* Ansible version:  X.Y.Z
* Operating System:
* Web Browser:

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Setup external logger with Splunk, send job events, run for >100 job events.

Inspect count of job events in Splunk versus Tower over a congruent filter.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Counts are the same

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Splunk is missing some events.

We know this to be related to a the error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/lib/python2.7/site-packages/awx/main/utils/handlers.py", line 63, in _wrapped
  File "/var/lib/awx/venv/tower/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests_futures/sessions.py", line 73, in wrap
    resp = sup(*args_, **kwargs_)
  File "/var/lib/awx/venv/tower/lib/python2.7/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 475, in request

    r = adapter.send(request, **kwargs)

    raise ConnectionError(err, request=request)
ConnectionError: ('Connection aborted.', error(104, 'Connection reset by peer'))
```

Since this is only intermittent, it is beyond the scope of external logger to resolve this actual issue (and is believed to be dependent on the Splunk server behavior). However, to fix this practically we need retry logic when sending the log.

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
1. Create a git repository with the following structure:
- hosts.yml:
```
all:
  host:
    host01
    host02
```
- group_vars/all.yml
```
all:
  ansible_user: root
```

2. In Tower, create a git project pointing to the repository where we have our inventory files.
3. In Tower, create a new inventory of type "Sourced from a Project" with the options "Overwrite" and "Update on project change" enabled.
4. After the first sync, check the "Details" tab in the inventory to check the "Variables" field. The content should be exactly this:
```
all:
  ansible_user: root
```
5. Back to the git repository, modify the "group_vars/all.yml" file removing the "all:" and fixing the indent.
```
ansible_user: root
```
6. In Tower, sync the project and the inventory again.
8. Go to the Inventory and check the "Details" tab, in the "Variables" field we can now see the "ansible_user" variable has been duplicated.
```
all:
  ansible_user:root
ansible_user:root

```
##### EXPECTED RESULTS
Tower should overwrite the variables:
```
ansible_user: root
```

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
Tower should not duplicate the variable "ansible_user: root":
```
all:
  ansible_user: root
ansible_user: root
```

##### SUMMARY

We have a workflow that passes some credentials (username and password) from Jenkins into Ansible Tower (passing "extra_var" via the API) to run a command on the remote systems.  These variables show up in the "Extra Variables" section and work fine when they are NOT encrypted with Vault.

When we use Vault to encrypt the variables and provide the appropriate Vault credentials to Tower, the process fails as the vaulted variables are not encrypted.

Attempting to simulate this in a simple example by pasting in vault encrypted variables results in the Tower GUI reporting "Error saving job template.  Error: Parse error, failed to parse variables."

See this RedHat support ticket for details:
    https://access.redhat.com/support/cases/#/case/02119398

Also see the attached screen shots showing the in-GUI extra variables setup attempt and error message.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* Tower version: 3.2.2
* Ansible version:  2.5.2
* Operating System: RHEL 7
* Web Browser: Firefox and Chrome (both currently latest released versions)

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

1. Create a vaulted variable:
    ansible-vault encrypt_string --name 'my_password' 'MySecretPa$$word!'
1. Ensure vault credential is setup with the proper password and added to the template.
1. Copy resulting "my_password" lines into the "Extra Variables" GUI, or pass it into the extra_vars section of the API call.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

 * GUI - "Extra Variables" section populated and used during execution.
 * API - The extra variables section is used and variables are properly decoded during execution

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

 * GUI - The GUI reports "Error saving job template.  Error: Parse error, failed to parse variables." and will not save new Extra Variables block.
 * API - The variables are passed into API but are not decoded or used by the job.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Screen shot showing vault password (screen shot "01"):

Screen shot showing Tower GUI error message (screen shot "02").

##### SUMMARY
Multiple Auth tests are broken due to futures dependency from django-radius update.  

We upgraded django-radius from 1.1.0 --> 1.3.3.  In this latest version, Futures v0.16.0 was added and is throwing an error on [this](https://github.com/robgolding/django-radius/blob/7824f978b9a143c642c6d089b4fd1e149b25db97/radiusauth/backends/radius.py#L2) import.  

This is throwing an error in our auth tests when they hit the radius backend, which seems to be hit when the LDAP backends are used as well.  



##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX: docker for mac

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
Example test to reproduce:

```
@pytest.mark.django_db
def test_ldap_login(admin):
        client = Client()
        auth_url = reverse('api:login')
        client.post(auth_url, {'username': admin.username, 'password': admin.password}, expect=200)
```

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Test uses 'django.contrib.auth.backends.ModelBackend' and passes.  

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Test fails with traceback below.

features, show how the feature would be used.  -->
1. Create a new workflow template
2. Add a job template that has a ansible script that references a variable Ex: - debug: msg: "{{ message }}"
3. Add two variables to extra vars, one that uses the name from step 2 and its value is a reference to another variable, the second variable uses the name that is referenced by the first and has any value. Ex. message: "{{ reference }}" and reference: "value"

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem. -->

Currently any custom include statement in nginx.conf will be overwritten during upgrade. This option would provide a variable for the include path in the inventory file. 

roles/nginx/templates/nginx.conf:
```
{% if extra_nginx_include is defined %}
    include {{ extra_nginx_include }};
    {% endif %}
```
Inventory:
```
#cat inventory |grep extra
extra_nginx_include='./conf.d/*'
```
##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0

##### COMPONENT NAME

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
<!-- For bugs, please show exactly how to reproduce the problem. For new
features, show how the feature would be used.  -->
I used an example: https://github.com/ansible/tower-example (cloned into /var/lib/awx/projects/)
I changed only playbook file (helloworld.yml) to use role defined in requirements.yml file:

```yaml
---
- name: Hello World!
  hosts: all
 
  tasks:
    - name: Hello World!
      shell: echo "Hi! Tower is working."

  roles:
    - yatesr.timezone
```

I created in Ansible Tower project with type manual. From that project I created template and ran it as a job and I get this error:

ERROR! the role 'yatesr.timezone' was not found in /var/lib/awx/projects/tower-example/roles:/var/lib/awx/.ansible/roles:/usr/share/ansible/roles:/etc/ansible/roles:/var/lib/awx/projects/tower-example
The error appears to have been in '/var/lib/awx/projects/tower-example/helloworld.yml': line 11, column 7, but may
be elsewhere in the file depending on the exact syntax problem.
The offending line appears to be:
  roles:
    - yatesr.timezone
      ^ here

but yatesr.timezone is mentioned in <project_dir>/roles/requirements.yml

Open workflow and create two nodes that run in parallel, create a third node that can connect to the two previous plays.

Unable to do so today.

##### SUMMARY
I have `ansible.cfg` file at the same root directory of the playbook file. With the following content.

```
[defaults]
host_key_checking = no
record_host_keys = no
ssh_args = -o ControlMaster=no -o ControlPersist=30m
callback_plugins = plugins/callbacks
gather_facts = smart
forks = 1000
private_key_file=~/.ssh/id_rsa
remote_user=ec2-user
log_path=/usr/local/var/log/ansible.log
```
But the job always pick up `root` as the user, though I could see in the logs that correct ansible.cfg file is picked up

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
Allow both an inventory and/or project sync on launch to be an option **in the job template**.

Our use case is that our inventory is dynamically sourced from Red Hat Satellite. During the deployment of a new server, a provisioning callback is done to configure the new server. However, the new server is not yet added to the inventory. Currently the inventory settings have it set to "update on launch" which is not ideal as the large inventory takes a long time to process for every Job Template that is ran. The inventory only needs to be updated during a few select Jobs.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.6
* AWX install method: DockerHub
* Ansible version:  2.5.3
* Operating System: RHEL 7.5

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
Create a new Job Template. There is no option in there to update an inventory and/or project whenever this Job is ran.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
There should be an option in the Job Template to update the inventory and/or project. This way it will update the relevant source of truth only for the Job Templates that have those options checked/enabled.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
Inventories and projects can only have their settings changed to *always* update on launch or *never* update on launch. There is no way to do this on a per-Job Template basis.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
Related RBAC settings are also something to keep in mind.

##### SUMMARY
There are "no default ordering warnings" on our functional tests that were introduced when we upgraded to Django 1.11.11.  

##### Possible Solutions
Option A: add an `ordered_by` in all of the get_queryset() and filtered_querysets() functions that are acting up in views.py.  
Option B: Make this change by adding ordering to the Meta class on the model.  
maybe we can find a sneaky metaclassed way to default to something like `order_by = ['id']`
Option C: Inherit from a common model that is `order_by = ['id']`.  It looks like this is already done for all models that use BaseModel, and is only an issue for custom models.  

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: X.Y.Z
* AWX install method: openshift, minishift, docker on linux, docker for mac, boot2docker
* Ansible version:  X.Y.Z
* Operating System:
* Web Browser:

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Run our functional tests.  



##### EXPECTED RESULTS

No warning messages

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Warning messages that our serializers are not ordered.  

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
It looks like this is already done for all models that use BaseModel, and is only an issue for custom models.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
The first time you create an OAuth2 token for a user, you must use basic HTTP Auth with the API using a password.  To make automation easier, it might be nice to have an `awx-manage` command that could be run as the `awx` user over ssh.

`awx-manage create_oauth2_token --user=some_user`

Such a command would create a write-scoped token for an existing user and return the token value.

related: https://github.com/ansible/awx/issues/1906

##### SUMMARY
We raised an RFE against redhat (when we was using ansible tower) to have the ability for passwordless access to the api. In awx 1.0.5 this was supposedly delivered with oauth2. However we now discover having looked at it, that you now need a password to get the initial token required for the rest of the api commands to work without a password. This is fundementally not much different to the previous authorisation model and still hinders automation as we now have to deal with a password and storing it in some location that is secure. 

We assumed that having read our requirement and indeed spelt that out on the github ticket (https://github.com/ansible/awx/issues/21) addressing this - that it was understood what we meant. I assumed that the move to oauth2 was to allow openssl public / private keys to be used to enable this. However this hasn't been done. So can someone look into this. 

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.6.8
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.5.3
* Operating System: rhel 7.4
* Web Browser: chrome

```
import os
import argparse

from ansible.parsing.dataloader import DataLoader
from ansible.inventory.manager import InventoryManager
 
 
def main():
  parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
  parser.add_argument('--list', action = 'store_true')
  parser.add_argument('--host', action = 'store')
  parser.add_argument('--pretty', action = 'store_true')
  args = parser.parse_args()
  loader = DataLoader()

  
  sources = '/nfs_mount/foo'

  inventory = InventoryManager(loader=loader, sources=sources) 
  inventory.parse_sources()
  out = {'_meta': {'hostvars': {}}}
  if args.list:
    for group in inventory.groups.values():
      out[group.name] = {
          'hosts': [h.name for h in group.hosts],
          'vars': group.vars,
          'children': [c.name for c in group.child_groups]
      }
    for host in inventory.get_hosts():
      out['_meta']['hostvars'][host.name] = host.vars

    print(json.dumps(out, indent=4, sort_keys=True))
 

if __name__ == "__main__":
  main() 
```

##### SUMMARY
We schedule a run of a playbook on all our inventories. We expect the instances handle the load correctly, but we see weird behaviours when playbooks are run against big inventories.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.6.5
* AWX install method: kubernetes
* Ansible version:  2.5.2
* Operating System: Linux
* Web Browser: Firefox/Chrome

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Have a small playbook that checks the expiration date of an SSL certificate.
Have 100 Inventories, varying from 2 hosts, to 150 hosts.
Have a kubernetes cluster with 5 nodes (4 cpus / 12G ram )
Deploy awx and scale it to 5 instances
Set the instances capacity to 70% 
Create an instance group with 4 instances only (80%)
Associate the playbook to that instance group
Run the playbook against all inventories.


##### EXPECTED RESULTS

The instances handle capacity correctly and all the playbooks complete.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
Very erratical results, several cases.

1.  After capacity is reached and playbooks seemingly run smoothly, one instance disappears, I guess by the AutoScaler
2.  That causes chaos, and capacity never gets distributed among the nodes, only 1 node seem to handle everything. It seems all the jobs that were kicked out of the dropped instances(s), end-up as part of the capacity calculacion for the remaining node , showin percentages going over +100%, 550% while I was writing this.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Pasting tower-cli commands used for easiness, I get the same bevaviour if I point a browswer of my choice at `https://tower.example.com/api/v2/jobs/?&elapsed__gt=9;status=running` and `https://tower.example.com/api/v2/jobs/?&elapsed__gt=9&status=running` (unsure if *;* or *&* needed when combining the query. I'm told *;* is the correct delimiter)

(It's just easier to paste one shell session than copypasta from multiple queries in the browser)

`elapsed__lt` and `elapsed__gt` should correctly compare the values (but maybe I'm just using it wrong).

* `tower-cli job list --all-pages --query status running --query elapsed__lt 100` should have returned *No records found.*

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
With the release of Ansible 2.4 it's possible to use **import_playbook** statements to add other playbooks into a playbook file. In some instances a playbook only contains these statements to import other playbooks and it does not contain any plays in them directly.

Example (openshift deploy_cluster playbook): https://github.com/openshift/openshift-ansible/blob/master/playbooks/deploy_cluster.yml

Not possible to add as job template either via UI and API until a minimum of one play is created somewhere in the file. For example:

- import_playbook: other_playbook.yml
- name: noop
   hosts: localhost
   tasks:
   - debug:
          msg: 'noop' 

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

- create a playbook with one or more import_playbook statement(s) only, try to add a job template and associate from a project.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Job template is created from a valid playbook that contains only imported playbooks in them.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Playbook doesn't show up in the list to add.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - Installer

##### SUMMARY
When you perform the integration between SAML and Ansible Tower/AWX the users that are federated on the SAML side will be created on Tower/AWX, but there is not any way to sync groups. The point of this issue is create a way to Map those groups that exists on SAML server agains the Orgs/Teams on Tower/AWX.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: latest
* AWX install method: all
* Ansible version:  a compatible one
* Operating System: Linux
* Web Browser: N/A

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

To perform the integration with SAML you must put the correct JSON definition on Authentication field regarding to Tower/AWX Configuration.

The point is that now you could Map users to a Team/Org using regex like this:

```json
SOCIAL_AUTH_TEAM_MAP = {
  "My Team": {
    "organization": "Test Org",
    "users": ["/^[^@]+?@test\.example\.com$/"],
    "remove": True,
  },
  "Other Team": {
    "organization": "Test Org 2",
    "users": ["/^[^@]+?@test\.example\.com$/"],
    "remove": False,
  },
}
```

But the point is to create a way to use a SAML attribute comming from the IDP to be mapped against the Orgs/Tems on Tower/AWX, something like this:

```json
{
 "Default": {
  "users": true
 },
 "Systems Engineering": {
  "users": true,
  "admins": [
   "groups.tower-admin"
  ],
  "remove_admins": false,
  "remove_users": false
 }
}
```

The content of groups array is:
```
groups = ['tower-admin', 'group1', 'group2']
```

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Create a Team/Org that maps with the groups which comes from SAML attributes

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API


##### SUMMARY
Currently  the TACACS+ authentication backend

https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/96370584062a15271abafab7fc557ac2879aa38c/awx/sso/backends.py#L225-L227

sends default value for client remote address 

https://github.com/ansible/tacacs_plus/blob/526b5a29c5656bbd8644accca238d1e9303dc272/tacacs_plus/flags.py#L81

The function `authenticate()` in  `TACACSClient` supports sending client remote address as parameter and should be used to correctly report client real address.

https://github.com/ansible/tacacs_plus/blob/9ba553f79efcc7b955001503d1953900ba6284a4/tacacs_plus/client.py#L158

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.5
* AWX install method: openshift, minishift, docker on linux, docker for mac, boot2docker
* Ansible version:  N/A
* Operating System: Any
* Web Browser: Any

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

TACACS+ authentication packet will contain clients real remote address.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Client remote address is always set to `python_device`.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
I manage a number of playbooks designed for automating highly-branched tasks that used to be performed by operators. The nature of this branching logic is highly boolean, and so I *very* frequently find myself using `multiple choice` type user surveys with `[true, false]` options. This requires more effort to make the survey, more effort to complete it, and requires care in input sanitation (where inputs are not `true` and `false`, but `"true"` and `"false"`. The `bool` filter is a life-saver.)

User surveys should support checkbox type fields, with `true` and `false` defaults.

Perhaps they could be trinary checkboxes, with `true`, `false`, and `omitted`, to be more in-line with other non-required extra variables, but that strikes me as a potential UI headache.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.5
* AWX install method: docker on linux

##### SUMMARY
We have a workflow with 20+ jobs. We are able to set the inventory source at the job level, but it becomes a bit taxing to have to modify each of the job templates whenever we want to switch inventory sources. It is also not feasible to copy job templates to have separate inventories per workflow, as it wouldn't be very long before we have more job templates than we can manage. It would be nice to be able to set the inventory source at the workflow template alone, and have the workflow level inventory take precedence over the job template level inventory.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.4.124
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.4.3.0
* Operating System: Ubuntu
* Web Browser: Chrome

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Create a workflow template with various job templates. In each job template, you have the ability to set the inventory source. In the workflow template, you can overwrite job template level variables, but you cannot overwrite the job template level inventory source.

##### SUMMARY
When I use e.g. terraform module with a binary that is downloaded in the same playbook, the credentials I have configured don't get passed to the binary it seems. The same playbook executed on my own machine with the exact same environment variables configured works just fine. In addition dynamic inventory script in AWX that uses the same credentials (OpenStack) also works..

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.5
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.5
* Operating System: CentOS
* Web Browser: Google Chrome

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
1. Configure openstack credential type on AWX (Built in are broken, I had to create custom ones for it to work) with the following environment vars:
```
OS_USERNAME=user name (can be AD)
OS_PROJECT_NAME=project name
OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME=user domain name
OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME=project domain name
OS_AUTH_URL=openstack auth url
OS_AUTH_TYPE=password
OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION=3
OS_NO_CACHE=True 
```
2. Put in your credentials
3. Write a playbook that deploys some infra using terraform with the following tasks:
```
- name: Download terraform
  get_url:
    url: https://releases.hashicorp.com/terraform/{{ terraform_version | default('0.11.7') }}/terraform_{{ terraform_version }}_linux_amd64.zip
    dest: /tmp/terraform-{{terraform_version}}.zip
  when: "'64' in ansible_architecture and 'Linux' == ansible_system and not stat_terraform.stat.exists and install_terraform"

- name: Install unzip to unarchive terraform
  package:
    name: unzip
    state: present
  when: install_terraform and not stat_terraform.stat.exists

- name: Unpack
  unarchive:
    dest: '{{playbook_dir}}'
    src: /tmp/terraform-{{terraform_version}}.zip
    mode: u+rwx
  when: not stat_terraform.stat.exists and install_terraform

- name: Check terraform again
  stat:
    path: '{{playbook_dir}}/terraform'
  register: stat_terraform
  when: install_terraform
  failed_when: install_terraform and not stat_terraform.stat.exists

- name: Lookup tfstate file
  stat:
    path: '{{terraform_path}}/{{infra}}/terraform.tfstate'
  register: stat_tfstate

- name: Lookup .terraform directory
  stat:
    path: '{{terraform_path}}/{{infra}}/.terraform'
  register: stat_tfmodules

- name: Init terraform if its downloaded (since force_init is broken in release currently)
  shell: 'pushd {{terraform_path}}/{{infra}} && {{playbook_dir}}/terraform init && popd'
  check_mode: no
  when: not stat_tfmodules.stat.exists and install_terraform

- name: Init terraform if its in path (since force_init is broken in release currently)
  shell: 'pushd {{terraform_path}}/{{infra}} && terraform init && popd'
  check_mode: no
  when: not stat_tfmodules.stat.exists and not install_terraform

- name: Run terraform
  terraform:
    binary_path: "{{install_terraform | ternary(playbook_dir+'/terraform', omit)}}"
    plan_file: '{{tf_plan | default(omit)}}'
    project_path: '{{terraform_path}}/{{infra}}'
    state_file: '{{stat_tfstate.stat.exists | ternary(stat_tfstate.stat.path, omit)}}'
    variables: '{{terraform_vars | default(omit)}}'
  register: tf_output
  environment:
    # This is not necessary, I think, it does the same thing regardless of me putting these manual lookups in
    OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME: "{{lookup('env', 'OS_USER_DOMAIN_NAME')}}"
    OS_PROJECT_NAME: "{{lookup('env', 'OS_PROJECT_NAME')}}"
    OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION: "{{lookup('env', 'OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION')}}"
    OS_PASSWORD: "{{lookup('env', 'OS_PASSWORD')}}"
    OS_AUTH_TYPE: "{{lookup('env', 'OS_AUTH_TYPE')}}"
    OS_AUTH_URL: "{{lookup('env', 'OS_AUTH_URL')}}"
    OS_USERNAME: "{{lookup('env', 'OS_USERNAME')}}"
    OS_NO_CACHE: "{{lookup('env', 'OS_NO_CACHE')}}"
    OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME: "{{lookup('env', 'OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_NAME')}}"
```
4. Deploy infra from your dev machine using the environment vars defined above. It should work.
5. Try to run the same playbook in AWX
##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Infra is deployed

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

`provider.openstack: Authentication failed`

N/A

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem. -->
The Python netaddr package is widely used and mentioned as [closely related to Ansible](http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_filters_ipaddr.html) but is not available in the default venv.  This rules out deploying other major projects including the popular [Kubernetes Kubespray installer](https://github.com/kubernetes-incubator/kubespray/blob/master/README.md).  Could netaddr please be added to the standard AWX task/web docker image virtualenv so that users do not have to maintain a custom Docker build for this one package?

##### ENVIRONMENT

* AWX install method: minikube (Kubernetes)
* Ansible version:  latest

* Web Browser: Chrome

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem. -->
This came out of discussion on #1757 
On update, the object id is not included in any of the fields logged by the ActivityStreamMiddleware, and there is no single field that could be logged to solve the issue for all object types - each type has a separate field in ActivityStream.
On create and delete, the object id is logged in ActivityStream.changes, as `get_allowed_fields` in `model_to_dict` (which populates changes) includes the id for all object types. On associate/dissociate, objtect1_pk and object2_pk are included in changes. So only update is missing the id.

#1757 Fixes this problem for Setting by logging ActivityStream.setting, but a more general solution is needed.
A few ideas:
- Include the object id in the changes field as in the case of create, delete, and associate/dissociate. ActivityStream.changes comes from `model_instance_diff`, which could easily be modified for this, but it could break any tools that depend on ActivityStream.changes to be only values that changed in the case of an update.
- Make the change in the middleware - log an object1_pk field and object2_pk  determined from the appropriate ManyToManyFIeld in ActivityStream. This wouldn't work for Setting, as ActivityStream doesn't maintain a relation to the Setting object that was updated.
- Switch to GenericForeignKeys or add object1_id/object2_id back to ActivityStream (they were removed in 61059fa1a4bd93f881eccf16d5f703bd8625ce74)

For all of the solutions above (except GenericForeignKey), I would recommend still logging the ActivityStream.setting field in the middleware OR finding a solution that logs Setting.key as part of the ActivityStream log, as this would make compliance easier. Currently, `model_to_dict` (which is used for ActivityStream.changes on create/delete) does not include Setting.key because it is a read-only field in the serializer. (See `get_allowed_fields`).


##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.5.22
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.5.0
* Operating System: Ubuntu
* Web Browser: Chrome

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

<!-- For bugs, please show exactly how to reproduce the problem. For new
features, show how the feature would be used.  -->
- Setup external logging to include activity_stream
- Change a JobTemplate or Setting
- Notice the activity stream logs doesn't include the id of the object changed (see actual results)


##### EXPECTED RESULTS

<!-- For bug reports, what did you expect to happen when running the steps
above? -->
- The object id should be present for all ActivityStream logs.
- The Setting key should be present for all settings creation/changes/deletion

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

<!-- For bug reports, what actually happened? -->
For JobTemplate update:

* Ansible version:  2.5.0
* Operating System: Ubuntu 16.04
* Web Browser: any

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

* Host an Ansible Project or a role in a mercurial repository on a server providing multiple SSL certificates via SNI
* Define a Project or also a dependency on a role in a roles/requirements.yml file
* Try an inventory update from the interface, or run `hg clone` for the same repository inside the web container

The mercurial repository is correctly cloned.

The clone operation cannot complete because of a certificate error:

```
[root@5caa6406da47 /]# hg clone https://user:password@a.example.com/rolename
abort: a.example.com certificate error: certificate is for b.example.com
(configure hostfingerprint <fingerprint> or use --insecure to connect insecurely)
```

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

The problem can be solved by installing mercurial 3.3.0+ inside the container, i.e. via `pip`:
https://www.mercurial-scm.org/wiki/WhatsNew/Archive#Mercurial_3.0_.282014-05-01.29
> * https: support tls sni (server name indication) for https urls (issue3090)

##### ISSUE TYPE
- Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
- UI
- Installer

##### SUMMARY
There are references in the documentation that AWX should be using ansible as installed in ``/var/lib/awx/venv/ansible`` but it's actually using ``/usr/bin/ansible-playbook`` with the ``/usr/bin/python2`` interpreter.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: awx==1.0.5.22
* AWX install method: ``docker-compose up`` from [geerlingguy](https://github.com/geerlingguy/awx-container)
* Ansible version: ansible==2.5.0

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

When the AWX instance is up with the demo template, edit the template to use the scm from here instead: https://github.com/dmsimard/ansible-tower-samples

It's a simple playbook edit that prints the value of the ``ansible_playbook_python`` variable.
This will return ``/usr/bin/python2``.

Additionally, you can also look at the shebang of the ``/usr/bin/ansible-playbook`` file, you'll see:
```
#!/usr/bin/python2
# (c) 2012, Michael DeHaan <michael.dehaan@gmail.com>
```

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

The documentation appears to reference ``/var/lib/awx/venv/ansible`` as where ansible runs from, i.e:
- https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/devel/docs/custom_virtualenvs.md
- http://docs.ansible.com/ansible-tower/latest/html/administration/tipsandtricks.html#using-virtualenv-with-at

But in fact, that doesn't appear to be the case as shown in the reproducer.
This feels like either a bug or perhaps the documentation is outdated.

I know AWX provides the ability to create a virtualenv and you can select it manually when doing templates but that's a bit bothersome.

I would like to have the ability to install something for the python interpreter ansible/awx uses by default without having to install it system-wide -- because right now ansible/awx uses the system python interpreter and libraries.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

I'm getting ``/usr/bin/python2`` as the interpreter so installing things in ``/var/lib/awx/venv/ansible`` are not effective since ansible will seek things in ``/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages`` instead.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
Currently, when an Ansible task specifies `no_log`, the summary output in AWX is not as explicit about this as it should be. Particularly with tasks with multiple items, we see output like
```
TASK [foreman_proxy : Slurp cert content for installation on the proxy] ********
14:16:04
ok: [foreman-sp.<domain>] => (item=None)
ok: [foreman-sp.<domain>] => (item=None)
ok: [foreman-sp.<domain>] => (item=None)
```
When clicked, it explains as follows:
```
{
    "censored": "the output has been hidden due to the fact that 'no_log: true' was specified for this result"
}
```

It would be clearer if the summary log added `<CENSORED>` or a similar marker for identifying at a glance why there is no information in the log.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.2.75
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.4.2.0
* Operating System: Mac
* Web Browser: Firefox

This conflicts with the same name used by the tower credential type

https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/d685815478b813d669dd55c248392a8eecb97923/awx/main/models/credential/__init__.py#L1194

We will be asking all playbook authors to change any environment var reference from `TOWER_HOST` to `AWX_HOST`, which has the same value.

##### SUMMARY
After configuring external logging settings SCM updates no longer work.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.5.18
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.5.0.0


##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

1) Setup a new project (I used git as an SCM source) and confirm an SCM update works
2) Configure external logging
3) Run an SCM update


##### EXPECTED RESULTS

SCM updates continue to work with external logging enabled

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

SCM updates stop working

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea


##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API


##### SUMMARY
Allow the assignment of some Organization roles to Teams.


##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
Currently you cannot assign a Team any Organization level roles, this is due to nature of how role assignments are implemented and how parent/children hieachies are caclutated. With the addition of the new focused admin roles for Organization resources it might be nice to revisit the idea of allowing a Team to belong to Organization level roles.

ISSUE TYPE: Bug
COMPONENT NAME: API

SUMMARY: 
POST request to http://<server-ip>/api/v2/job_templates/<template_id>/launch/
responds with
{
    "detail": "You do not have permission to perform this action."
}, but
GET request to http://<server-ip>/api/v2/job_templates/<template_id>/launch/
Succeeds, and responds back with the template details.

ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.5.19
* AWX install method: docker for linux
* Ansible version:  2.5.0
* Operating System: Centos 7
* Web Browser: POSTMAN Request

STEPS TO REPRODUCE
1. Create Application in AWX
2. Follow https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/ac70945071bec9bb1cfdfed328c13c3b2d1fbd39/docs/auth/oauth.md to create a new Auth Token, and bind it to the application.
3. Ensure that the token has write permissions
4. Fire a GET request to http://<server-ip>/api/v2/job_templates/<template_id>/launch/, to confirm that the access has been granted.
5. Fire a POST request to http://<server-ip>/api/v2/job_templates/<template_id>/launch/

EXPECTED RESULTS
Job gets invoked.
ACTUAL RESULTS
403 Forbidden: 
{
    "detail": "You do not have permission to perform this action."
}

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
Currently, the credential field is required in the UI.  However, there are scenarios where it makes sense to have a job template with no credentials at all.

For example, Tower running in AWS may be installed on an EC2 instance with an IAM role assigned that grants it privileges to manage other parts of the AWS infrastructure, without requiring any tokens or keys.

You can get around this by assigning 'Demo Credential' (or some other meaningless credential) to the JT, but it seems inelegant to require this.

##### ISSUE TYPE

 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME

- awx_tasks

##### SUMMARY

This idea is to use signed SSH certificates, provided by Hashicorp Vault. 
You can check https://www.vaultproject.io/docs/secrets/ssh/signed-ssh-certificates.html.

I want to stop deploying public keys, and use short-lived signed certificates provided.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
Updates in Roles are not consistently brought in to awx


##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Primary Repo:  Junk repo with only playbook calling one test role.  It also contained (2) naming variations of the rolesfile with (3) roles declared in it (files where identical bases the name, but didn't have to be).
Roles:  (2) random roles, not really used for testing.  (1) test role just echoing a variable.

1 - Create project, inventory, job template using the above.  Set project to update on launch and delete on update.  Cache timeout = 0
2 - Trigger job template, view/record echo statement
3 - Repeat step # 2 for a total of (5) attempts.
4 - Modify the variable in the test role and push the changes.
5 - Repeat steps # 2 and # 3.
6 - Repeat step # 4 (5) times.

In all my tests, this always failed within the (25) job runs.  Failure = the output in Ansible Tower console regarding the echoed variable did not match what was pushed to the test role.  NOTE - in all cases the project update output showed that the ansible-galaxy command ran and was "changed" for each of the "rolesfile" and appeared to be correct on the filesystem.

The interesting observation that we found was that if we remove the "when" statement noted above (ie. trigger the find and ansible-galaxy tasks on repo change), the above mentioned failures disappeared.  The project update output still showed the same "changed" for the ansible-galaxy task, as these always triggered due to delete on project update.


##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Correct roles being pulled into awx.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Rolls remain unchanged.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

We've done the following already:
-  Changed the ansible stat detect requirements.yml to a find looking for "rolesfile", "rolesfile.yml" or "requirements.yml" within the entire repository.
-  Update the ansible-galaxy command to iterate over all of those paths and extract the roles.
-  Both of these tasks are blocked off and only trigger when a change was detected in the primary repo or obviously if the project was deleted on update.

related #106

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report (I think)

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
When launching a job template with credentials that require passwords at run time, the api accepts the following format in the POST:

```
{
    credential_passwords: {
        ssh_password: "foo",
        become_password: "bar"
    }
}
```

When hitting the relaunch endpoint for the same job, the api throws a 400 if the passwords are formatted like they are above.  I think the api is expecting them to come in like:

```
{
    ssh_password: "foo",
    become_password: "bar"
}
```

I _think_ that this is a bug.  I'm pretty sure that the format directly above is the legacy format (pre-vault credential changes).  There could be a good reason why the api expects this format for relaunch but I figured I'd better make an issue just in case this was missed.  If this gets closed without any API changes then the UI will need a bit of work to make sure that the format matches up.

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Outlined in summary but the basic gist is:

1) Create a credential that requires password on launch
2) Create a JT that uses the credential in step 1
3) Launch a job with that JT
4) Try to relaunch the job and pass credential passwords in the specified format

<!-- For bug reports, what actually happened? -->
The script chokes on serializing ProtocolTypes to JSON. Calling `protocol.name` resolves this by putting the string into the dict, instead of the entire object.

##### SUMMARY
Github Team/Organisation authentication gives a 502 with Django error - "You have multiple authentication backends configured and therefore must provide the `backend` argument or set the `backend` attribute on the user." The user is authenticated, but isn't able to log in to AWX.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.4.62
* AWX install method: Docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.4.3.0
* Operating System: Ubuntu 16.04
* Web Browser: Mozilla Firefox 59.0

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Fresh install of AWX, setup of Github team authentication by adding the client ID/client secret/team ID, and then trying to log in using a Github account of the organisation.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

User logs in properly using Github credentials.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

502 at /sso/complete/github-team/. The user is actually created and correct permissions are assigned according to the team/organisation map, but the log in doesn't happen.

##### SUMMARY
Token creation for Applications with the implicit grant type that are public type form the `api/o/tokens` endpoint currently does not work.   

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: X.Y.Z
* AWX install method: openshift, minishift, docker on linux, docker for mac, boot2docker
* Ansible version:  X.Y.Z
* Operating System:
* Web Browser:

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

<!-- For bugs, please show exactly how to reproduce the problem. For new
features, show how the feature would be used.  -->

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

```
curl -kX POST "https://localhost:8043/api/o/token/" -d "grant_type=password&username=root&password=reverse&scope=read" -u "vwyeo1gtZWMJuJgEdPMdS1X9f8vRSSLxlqF4YAPN"
```
Should yield a token if the user is logged in to AWX with session auth.  

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

```
{"error": "invalid_client"}
```

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

This is likely due to how the client_secret is "removed" from implicit applications.

##### ISSUE TYPE
<!--- Pick one below and delete the rest: -->
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
<!-- Pick the area of AWX for this issue, you can have multiple, delete the rest: -->
 - API

##### SUMMARY
When an access token is made for an implicit grant, a refresh token should not be made.  This may be done correctly at the `api/o/token` endpoint, but needs to be fixed at the `api/v2/tokens`, `api/v2/applications/N/tokens`, and `api/v2/users/N/authorized-tokens`.  

Based on: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/active-directory-dev-understanding-oauth2-implicit-grant

> The implicit grant flow does not issue refresh tokens, mostly for security reasons. A refresh token isnt as narrowly scoped as access tokens, granting far more power hence inflicting far more damage in case it is leaked out. In the implicit flow, tokens are delivered in the URL, hence the risk of interception is higher than in the authorization code grant.


##### ENVIRONMENT
awx: 1.0.4.94

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

1. Make implicit application with POST to applications endpoint.
2. Create tokens for this application
3. Using dbshell, you can see that a RefreshToken is made.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

No RefreshTokens should be made for tokens made for applications with implicit grants.  

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
There are.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

1. Verify if this works or not with a curl to `api/o/token`
2. Conditionally remove creation of RefreshToken from the token serializers.

##### SUMMARY
My machine running AWX has 4GB. When process start, everything is well. After a few hours/days, the web docker is filling up the RAM and random processes OOM (usually tasks because celery creates and deletes workers all the time)

If I restart the `web` docker, I'm good again for a few hours.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.3.58
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  I guess it's irrelevant but 2.4.3.0
* Operating System: Debian
* Web Browser: N/A

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

From a clean instance, on a machine with 4 GB (corresponding to official recommendations)
- Define 1 organization, 2 projects, ~20 job templates
- Launch about 10 jobs per day

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Works

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Out of memory errors frequently, tasks marked as failed because they disappeared from the broker...

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

```console
$ free -hm
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:           3,9G        3,4G        159M         97M        290M        137M
Swap:            0B          0B          0B

$ docker-compose restart web
Restarting awx_web_1 ... done
# (navigating on the website, making sure it has loaded the code)
$ free -hm                          
              total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:           3,9G        1,2G        2,4G         97M        324M        2,4G
Swap:            0B          0B          0B
```

I'll try to find OOM output, but, as you guess, they're exceptions when allocating stuff.

**EDIT** Forgot to mention: I've used `top` in the docker to verify that it's actually uwsgi and not daphne or nginx that's taking all the space.

##### SUMMARY
<!-- Briefly describe the problem. -->

When using the set_fact method and the variable to set involves using a template, AWX intermittently throws the following templating error:

`"msg": "Unexpected templating type error occurred on ({{ ((dir_output.stdout_lines[0])[-1] | regex_search(regexp,'\\\\g<fs>') | list)[0] | int }}): 'NoneType' object is not iterable"`

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.4.78
* AWX install method: docker on linux,
* Ansible version:  2.4.3.0
* Operating System: Red Hat 4.8.5-16
* Web Browser: Google Chrome Version 65.0.3325.162 (Official Build) (64-bit)

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
<!-- For bugs, please show exactly how to reproduce the problem. For new
features, show how the feature would be used.  -->

To reproduce, use the set_fact method and try to set the variable value based upon the result of a regular expression using a template:

For example:

`    - name: Check flash directory free space
      asa_command:
        commands:
          - command: "dir {{ new_image.filesystem }}"
      register: dir_output
    - name: Record number of bytes free within Flash
      set_fact:
        flash_free_space: "{{ ((dir_output.stdout_lines[0])[-1] | regex_search(regexp,'\\g<fs>') | list)[0] | int }}"
      vars:
        regexp: '(?P<fs>[0-9]*) bytes free'`

The code snippet above looks to record the number of bytes free within the flash directory of a Cisco ASA device by looking at the end of the output and locating the value next to "bytes free".

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

<!-- For bug reports, what did you expect to happen when running the steps
above? -->

The following result is expected:

`"ansible_facts": {
        "flash_free_space": "154906624"
    }`

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

<!-- For bug reports, what actually happened? -->

The following result is observed, albeit intermittently:

`"msg": "Unexpected templating type error occurred on ({{ ((dir_output.stdout_lines[0])[-1] | regex_search(regexp,'\\\\g<fs>') | list)[0] | int }}): 'NoneType' object is not iterable"`

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

<!-- Include any links to sosreport, database dumps, screenshots or other
information. -->

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME

##### SUMMARY
The AWX UI doesn't appear to refresh for on-going tasks. For example, starting a job, the job always remains at pending unless you manually refresh the page.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.4.70
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.4.3.0
* Operating System: RHEL7 Docker
* Web Browser: Chrome and Firefox

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
Start a job of any kind.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS
The UI should automatically refresh as the job goes from Pending to In Progress to Complete and the activity log to automatically update.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS
The job appears to stay in pending until the browser is manually refreshed.

This did work in earlier versions of AWX. Is this a new regression?

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.2.327 
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.4.2.0

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
Email to Forum resulted in the following exchange, prompting me to open an issue. Transcript:

Matthew Jones <majones@redhat.com>

At one time we put the username in as an extra var but it looks like that's somehow being omitted from anything ad-hoc jobs right now. Can you open an issue for us to add that and the email address back to job runs?  I'll point out that, even when populated, it will not be populated when jobs are launched via schedules etc.

------
Howdy everyone,

Wondering if you could direct me to what I am looking for.

When you launch a template and the job starts, one of the details of the job, is "Launched By" and the username of the user. If you click on the user, it shows you a username, first and last name and email address.

In my survey that builds EC2 instances, we have a filed for person launching the template to enter their email address. That info is used to add a tag to the EC2 instance called "Requestor".

I was wondering if there was a way to access the WebUI variable for "Launched By" users email address and auto fill my survey filed that asks for the info.

Thanks!

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
When the 'Delete on Update' and 'Update on Launch' options are activated in an SCM project, it should be possible to execute several different or the same playbook within one project.

The background is, that in our case each project is executed on 3 to 4 inventories. However, when I have only one inventory and start several different playbooks on it at the same time, the issue also occurs.

 Here, a function should be built which creates a working copy of the content, e.g. after an SCM update, on which it can work. Further, an SCM update should be able to wait for another update until the loaded version was copied (or relocated) into the working directory.

##### ISSUE TYPE

##### COMPONENT NAME

 - UI

##### SUMMARY
When setting up a project from a repo on GitHub (private or public) the sync of the repo fails. I believe this is due to the fact that the AWX is required to go through a proxy to get to the outside world.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.4.3.70
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.4.3.0
* Operating System: RHEL 7.4
* Web Browser: Chrome 64

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Directly after install go to Projects and add a new Project that is hosted on GitHub. Fill in correct parameters for Project. Save. The project will fail to be pulled when you are behind an outbound proxy.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

The project to be pulled.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

The project pull fails. Says to look at STDIO but nothing is displayed.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

I have read through (http://docs.ansible.com/ansible-tower/latest/html/administration/proxy-support.html) but I believe this is when a proxy is in front of AWX for inbound traffic.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY
We want to prevent Org admins being able to create local users within tower. All our controls are based around ldap groups. We want to prevent teams with their own orgs being able to create local users in awx, as this breaks our standard. We therefore need finer grained RBAC rules. 

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.1.173
* AWX install method:  docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.4.3
* Operating System: RHEL 7.x
* Web Browser: Chrome

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY

AWX currently sets no CORS policy. This means that all cross-origin requests from a browser are denied.

While secure (fail-closed), a user may want to build a frontend that talks to the API, and therefore conditionally allow some domain requests. This would require AWX to have a CORS policy that allows some user-configured domains.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: any

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

This would be off by default.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY

The `help_text` of a credential type field is defined inside of the JSON definition of the fields in the database, getting translations for this is different from ordinary fields and will take extra work to solve.

This is only a problem for managed_by_tower credential types. Users will write help text for their custom types in whatever language they prefer.

Right now the `help_text` is static. This issue is to make it translated like how other text is translated.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: any

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY

Someday, django-polymorphic might implement https://github.com/django-polymorphic/django-polymorphic/issues/198.

If that glorious future comes to pass, we should use it.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: any

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY

We pass `*_user_name` and `*_user_id` to jobs launched by a user. It could be useful to pass other
user fields (email, etc.) or perhaps the whole user structure.

* AWX version: any

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

This should come with the understanding that fields beyond username/id are mutable by the user in many cases.

```json
        }
```

It puts the unified job template id in the summary fields, but we would probably prefer the full set of information like jobs. This issue is to handle these cases broadly for all similar scenarios.

##### ISSUE TYPE

##### SUMMARY

The activity stream is currently very fine-grained. While this allows detailed look at changes, this does lead to verbosity.

Many edits in AWX are a series of related changes - adding a user + associating it with an org/team. Adding a job template + adding a survey + adding permissions + adding notifications. An inventory update creates a flurry of activity stream entries for associating hosts to groups.

This leads to a very verbose activity stream, and collapsing some of these into single larger events may be useful.

* AWX version: any

* Operating System: Red Hat 7.4

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API
 - UI

##### SUMMARY

Followon of https://github.com/ansible/awx/issues/1207

Essentially, once we can register an isolated node (or something like it) on demand, there's no reason how AWX runs jobs can't change to a simple:

- create job
- spin up a per-job-run container
- run job
- kill container

This has many followon questions:
- does this obsolete instance groups?
- how does this work with custom venvs?
- what's the best mechanism for passing the runtime environment?

In general, this requires that we be able to talk to our container orchestrator to spin up the job running containers. So this may limit supported platforms.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: any

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

##### ISSUE TYPE - Bug Report ##### COMPONENT NAME - API ##### SUMMARY `/api/v2/workflow_job_template_nodes/:id/credentials` gets reverted back to an empty array when the user changes the node from failure->success. I suspect that this happens no matter what you change the edge type to but I haven't tested all the cases. ##### ENVIRONMENT * AWX version: 1.0.4.64 ##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE 1) Create a Job Template and select PROMPT ON LAUNCH for credentials 2) Create a Workflow 3) Add a root node (the details of this node are not important) 4) Add a on failure child node extending from the root using the template created in step 1 and select some additional credentials when creating the node. (this will cause `/api/v2/workflow_job_template_nodes/:id/credentials` to be populated) The workflow should look like: 5) Change the edge type of the child node from On Failure to On Success -> this is where the credentials seem to get wiped. In the UI, the following requests are made: 1) POST - `/api/v2/workflow_job_template_nodes/:id/failure_nodes/` with the payload `{id: 2, disassociate: true}` 2) PUT - `/api/v2/workflow_job_template_nodes/:id/` with whatever the node overrides are (this step is only necessary if the user has _changed_ something in the prompt modal but we make the request every time) 3) POST - `/api/v2/workflow_job_template_nodes/:id/success_nodes/` with the payload `{id: 2}` ##### EXPECTED RESULTS Expected contents of `/api/v2/workflow_job_template_nodes/:id/credentials` to remain the same while POSTing to the different node buckets. ##### ACTUAL RESULTS `/api/v2/workflow_job_template_nodes/:id/credentials` returns empty array after POSTing to the different node buckets. The UI for this workflow node prompting is currently in a local branch but I expect to have a PR up in the next 24 hours or so than can be used for testing. This could be reproduced through the API browser though with enough effort.

I verified in the docker-container that the project uses the correct git checkout. I even deleted the project and recreated it. awx also tells me that its using the correct commit id, where the user-id is `505`.

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
If you have a workflow that runs multiple jobs from the same project in parallel they will interfere with each others galaxy roles install. When each job kicks off it triggers a project scm full update which run ansible-galaxy install with a --force flag. 
https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/5370c5e07d701bb4c97381a4969f818339f01db2/awx/playbooks/project_update.yml#L142
This --force flag will replace the roles in the project and if another job is already running through those roles certain files will go missing at the point the other jobs try to use them. I have mostly encountered this with template files (presumably because these are looked up as needed, where as other files are potentially looked up and evaluated when an the ansible-playbook command starts up).

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: 1.0.4.33
* AWX install method: docker on linux
* Ansible version:  2.4.3.0
* Operating System: CentOS 7
* Web Browser: Chrome

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

1. Create a project with two playbooks and a galaxy requirements.yml file in the roles directory
2. Add the project to AWX
3. Create two job templates from that project (one for each playbook)
4. Create a workflow that runs both job templates at the same time
5. Execute the workflow


##### EXPECTED RESULTS

The two job templates execute in parallel successfully

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

One of the two jobs fails due to the roles files being replaced after it started executing.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

The problem seems to be more pronounced as more jobs run in parallel in the workflow. Quite possibly there is a way of stopping the project from updating for each job template execution, I'm quite new to AWX and maybe there is something I'm missing



https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/5370c5e07d701bb4c97381a4969f818339f01db2/awx/playbooks/project_update.yml#L142

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Bug Report

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY

We currently only handle `scm_delete_on_update` for check jobs. (See https://github.com/ansible/awx/commit/1a946d51c13131103561c97c076f628589cdae69).

This leads to weird semantics.

The option originally existed to handle cases where jobs may leave temporary files in the repo, or other similar issues. Now imagine the following:
- update_on_launch is set
- delete_on_update is set

If the update on launch runs on node A, records a revision of X, and the job then runs on node B which already has revision X... nothing will actually be deleted before the job runs. That doesn't mesh with what the expected use of the option is.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: any

##### ISSUE TYPE
 - Feature Idea

##### COMPONENT NAME
 - API

##### SUMMARY
It is difficult (and probably theoretically impossible) to write idempotent scripts for workflows in AWX.

Branches can't be distinguished from each other in a general sense. There's no _invariant_ identifier that a client can use to know that they are consistently modifying one branch versus a different branch.

This comes up if you try to write code that will create a particular workflow on a tower instance. Here is the 2nd of two such attempts I know of:

https://github.com/ansible/tower-cli/pull/479

AWX should provide a field on the node to make this easier.

##### ENVIRONMENT
* AWX version: all
* AWX install method: openshift, minishift, docker on linux, docker for mac, boot2docker
* Ansible version:  N/A
* Operating System:
* Web Browser:

##### STEPS TO REPRODUCE

Observe that all resources have name and/or description.

Look at workflow nodes.

##### EXPECTED RESULTS

Doesn't have to be name or description, but just any filterable field that a client can set would make client scripts (and Ansible modules) for workflows robust.

##### ACTUAL RESULTS

Workflow nodes do not have any client-writable attribute that can be later used to address it.

##### ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

Ping @john-westcott-iv

Here's the story, the `__init__.py` of the sso app has some heroic logic (written by @cchurch) in order to avoid a segmentation fault in CentOS triggered in a library that it uses.

https://github.com/ansible/awx/blob/f9079953744af1d79de11148a6e49f2ef38c94be/awx/sso/__init__.py#L4-L23

Related issue for the library https://github.com/onelogin/python-saml/issues/30#issuecomment-75954988

Within the current batch of dependencies, it was found that a segmentation fault occurred (borking the entire app) on version 2.2.3 of python-saml, but not version 2.2.2. This is what changed between the versions.

https://github.com/onelogin/python-saml/compare/v2.2.2...v2.2.3

Note that the monkeypatch changed things with the `dm.xmlsec.binding`, and that the upgrade of python-saml upgraded `dm.xmlsec.binding`.

Clearly these things are connected.

It looks like we need to alter the monkeypatch logic in `awx/sso/__init__.py` to be compatible with python-saml>=2.2.3 (specifically _its_ updated dependency,  `dm.xmlsec.binding` 1.3.3).

I'm carding this out separately so it doesn't hold up the timeframe of the rest of dependency updates.

because some people are already assuming we support it...

https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/27376/files#diff-f5b4ed56691a28c106adf759d95de084L128

The Template executes on all hosts of the Smart Inventory.
